course.subject: ACCT
course.name: Principles of Accounting I
course.description: For SB&M students, and programs that designate the course as a required/specified elective course. This is the first course of the principles of accounting sequence. Introduction to the concepts and principles of financial accounting, including the analysis, recording, and reporting of business transactions and preparation of financial statements.

reviews.author: ustisfun
reviews.title: Impolite prof with noninteractive learning atmosphere
reviews.comment_content:
The first thing that I would like to say is that even non-BAFS students, like me, can handle this, though those who studied BAFS in DSE would definitely gain some advantage. So don't feel sad even if you're a non-accounting high school student!

This course covers some basic concepts for accounting, such as four financial statements and components. I believe other people from the forum has already copy and pasted the info, so I won't do it here.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sorry for the upcoming rambling guys, I just want to tell you how awful he is!!!!!

Dennis is not bad in teaching. He does teach us something, and his English is proficient compared to other prof. Rather, I often found Dennis being utterly rude, which really affected the learning atmosphere. Many people in this page praised Dennis for being a great teacher and you'll probably think I'm just a 打手 who got a bad grade (though merely an A-). So allow me to explain.

Dennis Chan is an impatient, strict and stubborn man who gets all-defensive easily, which often put me and my classmates off. One time I asked about why my classwork was deducted by 30% in a neutral manner, & he responded with a very long message condemning me about not reading the guidelines... To be frank, I did not intentionally put my full name in wrong order, and that you didn't write in the rules that the order is to be put right, but merely 'full name as stated in student ID card'. Both of us have the responsibility to fix the issue, and besides, it is my grading that is affected, but not yours. There is no reason for him to be so angry :)

Second, he loses patience easily when you ask him more questions in depth, and it often feels like he is angry with students. After such undesirable experience with him, I just feel frightened whenever I ask him something via email. (Ironically, he only smiles and nods with know-it-all non-locals who interrupts in the middle of his sentence and raise questions.) I really wanted to learn more about the accounting mechanics, but unfortunately Dennis is not the prof that I should ask for.

Third, he sometimes puts up classwork that are not even mentioned in class (he mentioned compensation expenses, but not the whole procedure). This is totally unfair to those who are willing to learn but don't have related knowledge, compared to those who had learnt such in high school ! By the way, his policy of having sudden quizzes at the end of some classes without prior notice makes me really nervous. But I guess it's just my problem lol

Lastly, remember to preview the slides before lectures because he assumes us to already know something about the concepts and thus will not explain the basic ideas. For instance, he won't tell you what a 'write-off' is, and he just jumps right into the journal entry steps, assuming that you already know it. He only kept giving us trivia that are only useful when you get the gist of the content/ want to get into accounting major.
reviews.comment_grading:
update: Eventually an A- for this course.

We got 8 classwork,
3 homework assignments &
a final assessment with 50 questions that are to be completed in 60 minutes.
The grading policy is super intransparent. He gives no details after the finals.

By the way, don't, and NEVER, ask Dennis about grading policies (absolute/relative, request for paper-checking), whether via email or in person. Otherwise, be prepared to be scolded by him :)))
reviews.comment_workload:
homework and classwork assignments are mostly done on MH connect, an online website that gives you access to our e-book (though most of us don't read it as it's lengthy) and online assignments.

The workload is not that heavy -- no mandatory readings or questions, but only several open-book online assignments during class (meaning, you have to attend classes even there's no attendance) as well as homework. But these are okay as it also helps you consolidate concepts that you've learnt in class.

Homework assignments are more time-consuming - it requires us to do a full accounting process. The third one regarding inventory systems was the hardest. I used like 3-4 hours cumulatively to complete it.

reviews.author: Karen Tang
reviews.title: Not friendly to non-BAFS student
reviews.comment_content:
The syllabus before the midterm basically matches with the BAFS DSE. It is extremely hard for non-BAFS students to catch up since the chapters are arranged in a weird position in my own opinion.

I think one of the chapters regarding adjusting entries is the hardest to catch up. This chapter requires students with no accounting foundation to categorize different items, and this consumes much effort. However, for some chapters after the final, the chapter summary actually clashes with the above chapter on adjusting entries to a large extent.

Generally speaking, I saw my friends getting almost full marks when they have studied accounting before. This is very frustrating for students like me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kelvin tends to use a lot of local Hong Kong shops as examples in classes, and even in Cantonese sometimes, which may be difficult for some non-local students to understand.

He also loves using many technical terms and specific accounting terms, before explaining them clearly before using them. It is easy for me to lose track of what he is talking about and soon I found myself falling behind and not understanding the following lecture materials even more.

He tends to do many examples using draft paper and youtube videos in the lesson, it may be beneficial to students who understand him, but not to students who found it confusing on all the calculations which he ASSUMES we should know .

His powerpoint only highlight the important point without explaining the rationale behind, so it is hard to understand without reading the materials in textbooks.

There are no lecture videos provided.
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal Grading. Only get mean but still manage to got a B.
Should note that the mean is quite high.

The in-class exercise will probably count towards the participation rate.
reviews.comment_workload:
Reasonable.
Only some in-class group exercises every alternative week and mid-term, final. BUT it is important to note that ONLY kelvin's class has CASE STUDY REPORT which was distributed for almost a month, which gives us plenty of time to finish and it is quite easy if you have done certain research on the given topic. Examples of last year's good works are also given.

reviews.author: Hermione Pang
reviews.comment_content: The beginning of the class involves mostly topics that have been taught and tested in the DSE BAFs curriculum. It is easier for BAFs students to catch up. Nonetheless, terms and accounting format may be a little bit different, so it may take some time for you to adapt to it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite a lot of interaction in class. Often encourage students to answer questions during class. Marks will be awarded to those who answered.
reviews.comment_grading:
In class 24%
Participation 6%
Quiz 1 10%
Quiz 2 20%
Final 40%
reviews.comment_workload: Not much work to be done. There may be some in-class exercises but they are relatively easy and takes very little time. Apart from that, quizzes are given.

reviews.author: 科大小毒毒
reviews.title: Very, very good and passionate professor.
reviews.comment_content:
Prof Chen makes the content so easy to follow that I spent almost no effort comprehending. If you go to class you can easily understand the content.

Only content in PowerPoint slides are mandatory to study for the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
If there is an S grade above A I would with no doubt give Prof Chen an S grade in teaching.

She tends to condense everything into her ppt slides in a clear and concise manner which emphasises the idea of understanding the concept behind Accounting rather than remembering all the Accounting equations or statements.

I reckon there are only a few heads loss, within 8 maybe, comparing with the first class in the semester. Almost everybody shows up in each class whereas attendance is not taken.

You can ask questions at any time on the Discussion board of Canvas and she will answer all of them very promptly. She can most of the time explains stuff very clearly on the discussion board and I find her answers particularly useful. She also patiently answers questions after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Slightly good grading.

In-Class Exercises: 24%
Class Participation: 6%
Quiz 1: 10%
Quiz 2: 20%
Final exam: 40%

Prof Chen virtually did the questions in the In-Class Exercises during classes. Plus, as long as you have submitted the exercises you will gain full credit for that column. 10 In-Class Exercises throughout the semester but only 8 were required.

There is only one class in the whole semester that requires your attendance. You have to answer a designated question in that class to get that 6% participation marks. A file that shows which day you have to go to class will be released after add-drop period.

Quiz 1 is very easy, just the very basics. The mean was approximately 28.2 out of 32. Quiz 2 is slightly more difficult but the mean was still 72/84.

BUT! The final exam is simply a pain in the arse. It is very difficult. An A4-sized, double-sided cheat sheet is allowed to be brought into the exam but you won't need to even have a glimpse on it, at least for me. The mean of the exam was 78/150 and the s.d. was 22.

I believe the mean grade is B.
Even my Quiz 2 score was more than 1 s.d. below mean and my final exam score was within 0.5 s.d. below mean I can still get a B-. Can't blame anyone for that grade because I stupidly gave up this course.

Not the greatest but certainly better than a number of courses out there.
reviews.comment_workload:
Can be zero workload.

For the in-class exercises, if you are busy with other stuff you can simply copy and paste the answers and simply submit it. Doesn't take you much time. It is at your discretion to decide practising or not.

All you have to do is to revise the ppt slides, not even the textbook actually because the exams are only based on those slides but you can still work on the textbook as I heard it enables even deeper understanding.

reviews.author: Lemon Hui
reviews.comment_content: This is a fina course. Professor always talks about stocks, how he short them and earn a fortune. At last, he didnt have enough time to finish the whole acct syllabus. This was a good news to me because those were not in the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: I like his teaching style. I love finance stuff. Moreover, acct and fina are closely related.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term is 45%
Final is 55%
4 bonus points are given to students who do news sharing or solve problems in class
I got 90/100 in mt, 94.5/100 in final and no bonus points. I got an A.
In the first lesson, he said he would give as many As as possible, and he kept his promise.
reviews.comment_workload:
Zero workload. No assignments, no projects.
All you need is to prepare for your exams.

reviews.author: grindingalways
reviews.title: For those who did not take accounting-related subjects in high school, DON'T lose hope!
reviews.comment_content: Basically this course will teach you the 4 fundamental financial statements with a thorough curriculum. The content is definitely quite complicated, especially for people who did not take any accounting subjects before. HOWEVER, I heard that a lot of non-locals always thought that locals would have an advantage in the course since they had taken accounting before. Allow me to clear up this misconception that this is not always the case. There are still a lot of local students who did not take accounting before (it is an ELECTIVE subject called BAFS under Hong Kong's high school curriculum). And I am one of those people. So I am just like those people who did not know ANYTHING about accounting until taking this course. To fully understand what Dennis said, I had to revise the notes, ask questions, do textbook exercises for countless times and it ended up an endless cycle until final. SO, instead of going on complaining you are in a so-called 'disadvantageous' position, why don't you turn it into motivation by working 10x harder than others?
reviews.comment_teaching: People say Dennis teaches well but I can only partially agree. Yes, he can deliver what he wants to say in a quite straightforward way, but the fact that he speaks too fast while cramming students with a bunch of seemingly useful info often confuses me. It makes me fail to jot down everything he says and understand what the lecture notes mean (becos Dennis will always provide additional details in class). Also, he will NOT provide any paper review session of no matter mid term or final. This is so unfair to students whose marks in mid term are not satisfactory, because even if they wish to learn from their mistakes, they CANNOT. Being said so, he will answer your questions via email in a prompt manner. So be prepared to ask questions frequently if you wish to perform well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Original scheme:
Classwork: 8%
Assignment: 12%
Term test: 30%
Final examination: 50%
After cancellation of class and the term test (which was replaced with a 'class exercise' where format=mid term, so it is just a name):
Classwork: 8%
Assignment: 12%
Class Exercise: 15%
Final Exam: 65%
My results:
Classwork: done all 6 in total
Assignment: 57/60 (mean 44.7, SD 12.29)
Class exercise: 62/80 (mean 51)
Final Exam: NOT revealed (wth man...)
If the assignment is very difficult, the exam would be EXTREMELY difficult. 60 MC questions within 70 minutes. I already did not know how to do the very first questions, and I just randomly picked the answers when I knew the time was running out. So... good luck.
Got an A in the end. Honestly I was expecting to get B- cos I thought I messed up the final - And also the very low transparency of the course. So I felt really lucky for it. Thank god.
reviews.comment_workload: Throughout the semester he only gave us an assignment and several classwork. For the classwork, they were done in class and Dennis said 'if you submit to me I am going to give you full marks regardless of the performance', so no pressure at all. On the other hand, the one and only assignment was VERY difficult. I discussed with a friend numerous times before we figured out the most appropriate answers, not to mention if you try to finish it all by yourself.

reviews.author: Kobe_chh
reviews.comment_content: I did not study accounting before but I think the content is quite easy if you are willing to spend time on Tang's exercise. The content would not be too much for the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tang is a boring teacher but he is passionate and well-prepared in teaching. He is willing to use after-class time to help his students in their studies.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Assignment 10%
Midterm 1 25%
Midterm 2 30%
Online final exam 30%

Midterm 1&2 is easy but the online final exam is extremely hard and lack of time, maybe prevent cheating.

Parti 4-5/5
Assignment 10/10
Midterm 1 91/100
Midterm 2 98/100
Final 55/100
I get ~83.65/100 and get an A-
reviews.comment_workload: Around one assignment in two weeks, workload is acceptable. However, there are two midterms.

reviews.author: EMK
reviews.comment_content:
YOU NEED TO BUY THE TEXTBOOK FOR CONNECT ACCESS FOR YOUR HOMEWORK

copy from others

Chapter 1: Introducing accounting statements
Chapter 2: Investing decisions and financing decisions and the accounting system
Chapter 3: Income statement and some operating decisions
Chapter 4: Adjustments, financial statements, and the quality of earnings
Chapter 5: Interpreting financial information
Chapter 6: Sales revenue, receivables, and bad debt
Chapter 7: Costs of goods sold and inventory
Chapter 8: Property, plant, and equipment
Chapter 9: Reporting liabilities & bonds
Chapter 10: Reporting bond securities
Chapter 11: Reporting and interpreting stockholders' equity
Chapter 12: Statement of cash flow
Chapter 13: Financial statement analysis

When compared to other professors, Wilbur included more " factual" knowledge (those in CH5). Honestly speaking, they should be part of our common knowledge but I just ignored them during that lesson and wrote them down in my cheat sheet. Just do so if you don't think you need to know these facts.

According to other posts all the contents are included in BAFS in HKDSE so it will be a huge advantage to those who have taken BAFS before.

Well, it may be somehow correct but as one who had no any business background, I think it doesn't matter. Everything is basic concept and Wilbur did not test some very complicated concept nor some concept that he did not mention before (although there are some in the homework but that's all due to the publisher). Therefore, based on my experience, just listen to his lecture and do some exercises in the textbook as practice can save your life.

Attendance is taken but you just have to answer some pulling questions online. ( P.S. If you have friend with you, just ask them send you the code or even ask them to answer the questions for you using another device will be fine) However, it is strongly advised that you should take the lesson especially if you have no background before. The pulling questions always helped me to clarify my concept so I think it will be helpful if you do them yourself.

Homework are not difficult and have UNLIMITED attempts which means that you can get all 20%. However, I don't think homework can help your exams so extra self-exercises are needed if you want to get good grades.

Midterm was terrible (mean is about 60% after adjustment) which forced Wilbur to add 20 marks for everyone ( it seems that upper quartile was 8X after adjustment) . Final was terriblly easy when compared to midterm and those from all other professors
(maybe Wilbur did so because of the midterm). However, no marks was released even when grade is given. I think Wilbur will make better adjustment on the difficulties later on so good luck.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wonderful English.
Also, he can deliver the ideas very clearly in an organised way.
When this comes with his pulling questions, you won't be puzzled for most of the concepts ( as long as you pay attention to his lessons)
He uses PPT from publisher but I think those are enough.
Some notes are given but I don't think they really helps. Just refer to PPTs is enough.

I didn't reached out to TAs so no comments.

P.S. quite handsome if with mask.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Online pulling question
Me: 5/5

Homework 20%
CONNECT from publisher, unlimited attempt.

Me: 20/20

Midterm exam 25%
TERRIBLE. More clearly, the concepts are not difficult but you don't have enough time if you are not familiar with the tasks enough. My recommendation is do more exercises in books.
An adjustment on the marks was done.
Me: 100/100

Final exam 50%
Very easy. You can do it within 1.5 hours while the exam time was 3 hours. I am quite sure Wilbur being a new professor is one of the reasons for the unreasonable difficulties. Therefore, situation should be quite different for his next semester.

No marks are given but should be somewhat 90 or above.

Letter grade : A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Homeworks about every two weeks. It does take you some time to do the homework especially if you are not familiar with the concepts. Also, the UI is somehow NOT user-friendly.

As what I have mentioned, you'd better do some self-practice if you have no background and want to get good grades. This takes most of your time but they worth it.

reviews.author: happystar
reviews.title: Better than I thought
reviews.comment_content: Her content is great, with her very detailed PowerPoint that highlights all the things we need. No need to read books in fact, ppt is enough!
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching.... um..  to be honest, I can feel her passion in teaching but just not interesting. The tone is flat which makes students fall asleep. In fact, I skipped lessons that quizzes are not required later on as they are not quite useful
reviews.comment_grading:
I deeply apologize for the previous comment, which said that she is a bad-graded prof.

I just received the grade, very surprising to be honest, although the final score does not release, I guess I will score no more than 20%, as the final is insanely difficult, to be honest. Interestingly, the grade turned out not that disastrous as I thought. I guess maybe because everyone died and I am the one that is relatively better.

Is she good-graded? I guess relatively yes.
Sorry for my previous blame on her, but just hope that next time don't change the grading policy just before the exam, which will really depress students.

PS: For every freshman, her final is insanely difficult (I predict no more than 20% for myself) but it seems that if you can answer only a little bit, it is enough to get a good grade.

Sorry Sorry Sorry Sorry Sorry Sorry sorry sorry sorry sorry sorry sorry Prof. Chan
reviews.comment_workload:
Huge! Huge! Huge!

every week:
1. Homework ~ takes around 0.5h to 2h depending on different chapters.
2. quiz ~ several mc or computational question usually, not hard but it makes you need study EVERY WEEKEND!

reviews.author: MANSI
reviews.title: MUST SEE for NON-BUSINESS Student!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic principles of accounting. Below are the detailed contents:

Chapter 1: Introducing accounting statements
Chapter 2: Investing decisions and financing decisions and the accounting system
Chapter 3: Income statement and some operating decisions
Chapter 4: Adjustments, financial statements, and the quality of earnings
Chapter 5: Interpreting financial information
Chapter 6: Sales revenue, receivables, and bad debt
Chapter 7: Costs of goods sold and inventory
Chapter 8: Property, plant, and equipment
Chapter 9: Reporting liabilities & bonds
Chapter 10: Reporting bond securities
Chapter 11: Reporting and interpreting stockholders' equity
Chapter 12: Statement of cash flow
Chapter 13: Financial statement analysis (Did not cover in this semester)

The content is mostly covered in the senior secondary if you have taken accounting before. Hence that would be simple for those who had studied accounting-related subjects before.

For those who didn't take those subjects before, GOOD LUCK. As one of them, my suggestion is to spend one or two hours every week to dig deep into the practices. This could really help in your final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Tang is much appreciated. He is a very passionate tutor. With every lecture, you could feel his passion for accounting.

His accents are clear without any of the Chinese accents. Besides, he seldom overrun his lectures.

He is also welcome to any kinds of questions. Since zoom lecturing is adopted this semester, he disabled the chatroom function as well. Therefore, you may need to open your mic and ask him directly. However, he is welcome to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scale:
5% Participation
25% Homework
30% Quizzes
40% Final

Participation:
As the online mode is adopted, Prof Tang uses IN-CLASS POLLING to take the attendance. You could get all 5% if you answer all the questions, no matter you are correct or not. There are various types of questions, including some true or false, concept checks, and calculations.

Prof Tang would release the answer of the in-class polling later on. I STRONGLY RECOMMEND looking back at those questions as they are similar to the type of questions that would exist in the final.

Homework:
Please look at the workload part thanks.

Quizzes:
Please look at the workload part as well. However, best 4 out of 5 quizzes will be selected for the score for quizzes.

Final:
I give his grading a C because HIS FINAL IS HARD AS HELL!. The type of questions that exist in the lecture notes and homework is totally different to those in the finals...

The length of each question is much longer than before. It is very challenging to finish all questions in time. The question type includes:
True or false
Selecting correct/ false statements
Calculation (Type-in)

As the calculations require you to type in the answer. You literally have no chance to make a guess...

Finally, I got only 30/100 at ate a C.

However, I still appreciate prof Tang effort and assistance in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
This is a light workload course since this is usually one of the courses you started studying in HKUST. You should not few much stress and tension.

Also, as a non-business student aiming to minor in business, this would be a helpful course as you may acquire some basic accounting skills useful in your future.

The workload is as follows:
5 Quizzes
4 Homework

Quizzes:
Held throughout the semester every 2-3 weeks. The contents are simple. Around 20 questions in which half of which are true or false questions. One-forth is checking correct/false statements. The remainings are calculations. If you keep up the steps with the prof you should get a mean score.

Homework:
A bit challenging. At the start of the semester, prof Tang only allowed 2 attempts for each assignment. Then he changed to unlimited attempts after he received some reflections from the students.

Therefore, you should be able to get a full score in this part.

reviews.author: shortiebrownie
reviews.comment_content:
(Online Semester)

Homework Quiz #1 (take home assignment)
Midterm Exam 1 (take home assignment)
Homework Quiz #2 (take home assignment)
Homework Quiz #3 (2 parts, Take home assignment)
Final Exam Part 1
Final Exam Part 2

Attendance not compulsory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Sidd is pretty chill. He explains concepts really well and speaks really good English. He uses a lot of real life examples in class and for assignments. Really recommend watching his lectures as he usually gives hints about homework in them.
He tries to make jokes in class, sounds like dad jokes, i dont think many people understand them, but at least he tries....
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Homework Quizzes 30%
The lowest score of homework quiz #1 or #2 will be dropped. Homework Quiz #3 cannot be dropped.
Q3 (15%) + the higher of Q1 and Q2 (15%)

Midterm 30%
Pretty easy take home assignment...

Final exam 40%
SUPER long, not enough time.... he said he made it hard because of online sem but seems like its been hard every year...

Can usually score more than 90% in all the assignments but that just raises the mean so can be hard to get good grade.

Overall got around 80% (B-)
reviews.comment_workload:
It's honestly not that much... he usually uploads the homework a couple hours earlier than he says so that gives you a bit more time to complete. Everything is open book so you have access to everything online.

You really gotta understand concepts well in order to answer the questions properly. His wordings can be confusing so make sure to clarify anything and everything with him.

It's not hard if you work hard... don't be like me... ga yau :)

reviews.author: Eva_207
reviews.comment_content: I've never done accounting before and I found it easy. However, Kelvin's class has covered less than other classes (skipped bonds chapter, shortened chap 9 and 12). The content is easy to understand if you read the textbook, which you have to pay for at the beginning of the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
From the very first lecture, he uses accounting terms that people with no background (like myself) wouldn't understand. It's also hard to follow since he talks very fast and uses such terms. He goes into a lot of detail regarding the most random things, but doesn't talk much about important parts. In fact, we spent a month on one simple chapter and rushed the last 3 chapters in the last 2 weeks.

I was basically taught by the textbook and not him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Take-home exercise 35%
Mid-term 25%
Final exam 40%

The take-home exercise is on a platform 'connect'. For the first few assignments there is an option that checks your answer, but later on it disappears. There are a total of 8 exercises, and only the best 7 are counted towards the final mark.

Surprisingly, the midterm and final exam were extremely easy. He only asked the most basic questions that you can answer by simply understanding the concept. Once again, I heard that students with other professors had incredibly hard exams.

I got 99% on the midterm, 99% for the take home exam, and did well on the final exam (didn't get detailed results), and got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to spend time practicing questions from the textbook. I've seen students that don't do this struggle. Once you do it and understand the concept, it's easy.

The take-home assignments each take around 1 hour to complete.

reviews.author: hypetrain
reviews.title: Don't reg Dennis Chan
reviews.comment_content:
Accounting 2010 will provide you with a better understanding of accounting's role within
the business world and its influence on society in general. Accounting impacts all areas of
society and it is therefore an enormous advantage for you to have an understanding of basic
accounting principles.
This course will cover a broad range of investment and financial accounting issues with
emphasis on their practical application in the business world. You will learn the
fundamental skills required to hold a managerial position or manage your own small
business as well as learning how to better manage your own personal finances. Even if you
do not intend to undertake an accounting major, you will certainly benefit from the technical
skills you develop in this course.
In addition to developing technical proficiency, this course has also been designed to
develop and enhance your creativity, professionalism, communication and inter-personal
skills. As importantly, this course has been designed to maximize your enjoyment and to
give you every opportunity to succeed.
reviews.comment_teaching: I'm mainly here to review Professor Chan's teaching. I read many reviews praising his teaching but it seems like Dennis in real life and his reviews show different styles and personalities. When I took his class, I would often find myself confused despite paying attention and trying my best to comprehend the materials. Dennis would often cram us with useless trivia that only someone who wishes to be an accountant would be interested in. The trivia would not be examined but I didn't know that at first. This led to me memorizing a lot of meaningless information. I also find Dennis quite rude to students. He wouldn't really be willing to answer questions through email and I saw him once scoff at a student when he asked the professor a question after class ended. It was a mostly negative experience being taught by Dennis. I recommend him to replace offering useless trivia with using real life examples to illustrate concepts and ideas.
reviews.comment_grading: Reasonable to somewhat harsh.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate.

reviews.author: puddypie
reviews.title: Steep Learning Curve
reviews.comment_content: The course itself is relatively difficult if you had not taken Accounting before during DSE / A-Levels. The learning curve is super steep. The content is easy to grasp but due to the extreme competition, you will be expecting very high mean. Be mentally prepared.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tang Chao is extremely passionate about accounting. It can be seen from the way he teaches the class. Very good english and very articulate guy. He tries to integrate the content of the course with real-life case studies. I personally really enjoyed learning from him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 14%
Classroom performance 6%
Midterm1 15%
Midterm2 15%
Final exam 50%

Personal Score:
MT1 76/100 (Mean 83.3/100)
MT2 92/100 (Mean 75.6/100)
Final 72/100 (Mean 62/100)

Score: B

Finals for Tang Chao is extremely difficult. Most left the hall feeling defeated and mentally tortured.
reviews.comment_workload: Fairly light workload. After every 1/2 Chapters, the professor will give a homework set for you to do. It is graded based on effort. Good platform for you to revise and know what are the important concepts of the chapter.

reviews.author: ustmoonie
reviews.comment_content: All about the 4 financial statements.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since there was only one month, the teaching was a little bit too rush. Actually, the instructor's English was not that good. You had to spent some time to understand what he said. Sometimes, the instructor just copied words from the textbook and didn't really understand them. So, you'd better spend some time after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% of the class get a range. I think everyone got 100% on quiz since the instructor only marked down repeatedly wrong question, so basically, you grade depended on your performence of the final exam.

Grading scheme:
20% Participations

reviews.author: ChrisLi2015
reviews.title: A Good Professor
reviews.comment_content:
She provides much account knowledge.
What she taught is quite useful and helps you understand many basic account knowledge that can be applied in reality.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She provides many explanation
She is very patient. When I have problems, she will always answer me. One time, I visited her office and saw that she offer a student a tutorial class because she found that he met some difficulties.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got only around 70% marks in the final examination. However, finally, I got a A+ from this course. It totally helps me.

You should also review the exercise she gives you and understand them through reading books yourself.

Sometimes, before the examinations, she will give some hints and let you have some benefits if you attend the lessons.

By the way, though the mid-term exams are quite easy, the final exam is extremely difficult. You should be very familiar with what you learnt before have the final examination.
reviews.comment_workload: For the whole semester, you only need to do 5 group assignment. If you want to get a better grade, you just need to answer some questions during lessons and then get the card.

reviews.author: Sofy Twilight
reviews.title: Good Grade Course and Can be Handled Easily
reviews.comment_content:
Just like the first half of HKDSE Accounting Module, with Cash Flow Statement
Journal Entries
Income Statement
Balance Sheet
Statement of Shareholders' Equity
Cash flow Statement
Accounting of PPE and Accounting of Inventory
Just these things, nothing special
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the teaching is ok, at least he read out PPT and gave the examples and did them by himself, his handwriting is quite good. Tbh for an accounting course you can't expect much regarding the teaching
reviews.comment_grading:
Very Good. Even I scored 62 in the Final Exam (Later improved to 70 due to the MC accident), I still got a B+ What a GENIUS course.

My sub-score: (before re-marking)
Homework: 34.55/35
Mid-term: 18.75/20
Final: 27.9/45
Total: 81.2
This results in B+, after re-marking I got 3.6 more total score which is 84.8 and I still got B+

For your interest I scored 5** in HKDSE BAFS Accounting Module, the university course, undoubtfully, shall give more challenge than that of HKDSE, just remember this. I overcome the HKDSE Accounting Module, but this doesn't mean the course can be handled that easily.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite low. Homework on McGraw Hill, One assignment a week.

reviews.author: ypl
reviews.title: Steven世一
reviews.comment_content: All the contents teach you how to write financial statements, including BALANCE SHEET, INCOME STATEMENT, STATEMENT OF STOCKHOLDERS’ EQUITY, and STATEMENT OF CASH FLOWS. First, you have to know how to prepare JOURNAL ENTRIES to adjust the incorrect information in the financial statements and finish the correct one.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The PPT from the publisher is quite lengthy
Steven will use his example and Excel to explain the concept, which is more straightforward than the PPT
The venue for the class is a big lecture hall, so it is hard to raise questions immediately when you don't understand the content
He will give you sufficient time to finish some in-class exercise, but if you do fast, you may feel bored
However, he carries a Hong Kong accent and you'll hear many "so"
He is so patient that you can ask him questions using Cantonese after the class, although it's already tea time
reviews.comment_grading:
Take-home assignment exercise (the best 5 submissions counted towards total assessment) 35%
Mid-term exam 25%
Final exam 40%
Best 5 assignments: 4 100 and 1 95
Mid-term: 100
Final: didn't release the score
Finally, I got an A+ in the course
MT details: one hr
Prepare a bank reconciliation 70M
Prepare journal entries for 3 events 20M
Explain whether recording a bad debt expense when uncollectible accounts receivable occur is more accurate 10M
I don't know how the mark is graded to each point but if you get all the answers correct, it's ok
Final details: 2 hr and 30 mins
10 MC 20M
Prepare journal entries for 16 events and show your calculations 20M
Prepare an income statement and show your calculation 10M
Prepare classified balance sheet and show your calculation 10M
Prepare a statement of cash flows by indirect method and show your calculations 30M
Explain whether the company will not go bankrupt if it is making a profit 5M
Explain whether the best way to approve credit terms are by the sales department 5M
By comparing the content of MT and Final, you'll see how unreasonable the final is
It took me 75-85 mins to finish 16 journal entries and rushed to finish the remaining part
It is more reasonable if one long question is cut and time is reduced to 2 hrs
I don't think I know all the contents for this A+, but maybe the mark is too small and I touched each question a little bit, so I got an unanticipated high mark that cannot fully reflect my knowledge
reviews.comment_workload:
only 7 assignments and you'll have at least one week to finish it
you may ask Steven about the HW to guarantee you got a full mark

reviews.author: lmaosiu4
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction
2. Balance sheet
3. Income statement
4. Adjustments
5. Sales revenue; Receivables and cash
6. Cost of good sold and inventory
7. Property, Plant and Equipment (PPE)
8. Current Liabilities

10. Statement of Cash Flows

He skipped bond as he said this may cause some confusion.

reviews.comment_teaching:
He explained accounting concepts clearly. He explained things deeply beyond the slides so that we can understand what is REALLY going on. I did not study BAFS in secondary school but I still managed to catch up. If you did not study BAFS in your secondary school, you may want to consider Kelvin. But make sure you don't skip lessons if you wanna earn a good grade.

He is also willing to answer questions, which helped clarify a lot of misconceptions. He has a high proficiency in English. The accent is easy to follow.

But a point to note is that you need to spend some time to sort out what is really important and what will really be tested in exams. Some explanations are just for your understanding but will not be tested.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme

Take-home assignment exercise (the best 7 submissions counted towards total assessment) 35% (Got full for all assignments)
Mid-term exam  20% (37/40) (Mean: 30.61, SD: 6.14)
Final exam  45%  (Not to be released)

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
As mentioned, he skipped a few topics. We study fewer topics compared to other professors.

Weekly assignments required, but manageable. He purposely reduced the number of questions in each assignment near the final exam and our workload is quite light especially towards the end of the semester.

No group projects and case studies. No quizzes. No attendance taking.

reviews.author: 科大公道伯
reviews.title: 我好中意sidd啊 但我個grade好爛啊 (係我問題 唔關佢事)

reviews.author: Rigbones
reviews.title: Excellent Professor
reviews.comment_content:
Half of it similar to DSE Acct, but the other half is new content.  Final exams will require complete in-depth understanding of the material.  Prior accounting knowledge is preferred but you still need to put effort into this course to get good grades.  If you don't have prior accounting knowledge it's ok too, just make sure you never skip lectures.

Ch1 Introduction to the course
Ch2 Investing and financing decisions and the accounting system
Ch3 operating decisions and the accounting system
Ch4 adjustments, financial statements, and the quality of earnings
Ch5 Interpreting accounting information
Ch6 Sales revenue, receivables, the bad debt
Ch7 Cost of goods sold and inventory
Ch8 Property, plant, and equipment
Ch9 Time value of money
Ch10 Reporting liabilities & bonds
Ch11 Reporting and interpreting stockholders’ equity
Ch12 Statement of cash flows
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great teaching, patiently answers students questions even though we keep asking the exact same question.  Clear focus and highlights details and important concepts.  Not reading powerpoints only.  He is a true accounting professor, congratulations if the system pre-regs him to you.

Some reviews say he is boring but I personally do not think so.  His teaching is detailed and will save you lots of time when studying.  He knows the difficulties students face when learning accounting and addresses them very well in his teaching.

He is extremely willing to hear students' opinions and help us out whenever we need, so if you have any problems just send him an email.

DO NOT SKIP LECTURES.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Homework 25%
Quizzes 30%
Final exam 40%

Participation is based on zoom polling.  Complete all zoom pollings in class and you will get full marks, even if you chose the wrong answer.

Homework involves 5 problem sets, and 10 smartbook exercises.  Besides the first problem set the rest are fairly short.  45 minutes should be more than enough for each.  Graded on accuracy, unlimited attempts.  The smartbook exercise is just a simple MC exercise graded on completion, designed to familiarize yourself with the content before class.  Make sure you don't miss any because they're practically free marks.

Quizzes consists of 5 quizzes, all MC, take the score of the best 4 quizzes.  Fairly simple, high mean, similar to textbook questions.

Final exam is all MC and fill in the blanks, huge difficulty difference from quizzes.  Focuses on concepts rather than computations.  Without perfect understanding it will be quite hard.

My grades:
Participation ?? (the grade was never revealed to us)
Homework 25/25
Quiz1  7.5/7.5, mean 6.37, median 6.7, sd 1.02
Quiz2  7.5/7.5, mean 6.54, median 6.5, ad 0.97
Quiz3  7.5/7.5, mean 6, median 6.1, sd 1.55
Quiz4  7.5/7.5, mean 6.21, median 6.5, sd 1.73
Quiz5  7.5/7.5, mean 6.2, median 6.7, sd 1.68
Take best 4 of 5 quizzes
Finals  82/100, mean 44.6, median 43.5, sd 15.96, max 85
Letter grade A+.

Tips for getting A:
Tang will tell you in the first class that the key to this course is practice, practice, and practice.  It is absolutely true.  Read the whole textbook (except chapter 5) and complete all textbook exercises (except chapter 1,2,5, alternate problems, and cases and projects).  Do so even if you took DSE accounting.  Quizzes have questions very similar to textbook questions so doing them will assure you score high on quizzes.  It takes about 7 hours to complete each chapter (reading + questions) without any distraction.  In reality phones are attention seekers so it will take you around 2 nights for 1 chapter.  Do them as soon as he finishes a chapter, or else you will not have enough time to finish them before quizzes.  

Textbook questions may be a bit on the easy side, but it is paramount for building good understanding, which will be crucial for the final exam.  You must fill every hole of doubt and question to score high on the finals, and the textbook questions will help you achieve that.
reviews.comment_workload:
Requires students to purchase a $350 McGraw Hill Connect account.  All HW and quizzes will be held on that software so make sure you purchase it as soon as he tells you to buy it.

5 problem sets, 10 smartbook exercises (read grading for more info)
5 quizzes, 1 finals

It looks like a lot but each exercise is fairly short, don't worry too much about it.

If you aim for B range, the workload is medium.  If you want an A+, be prepared to work your ass off.

reviews.author: M331
reviews.title: Easily the worst teacher I have ever had.
reviews.comment_content: The course content is quite interesting and gives you a decent basic understanding of financial accounting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Before I start I just want to preface by saying that I got an -A in the end, which I was quite happy with all things considered, and I am not writing this review in an attempt to "get back at him" for giving me a poor grade.

There seems to be quite a big divide in opinions when it comes to Dennis. Some students seem to love him and enjoy his harsh style of teaching, but a lot of other students find him unnecessarily mean and defensive when it comes to answering questions and grading. I am definitely in the second group.

He takes away 30% of your grade for all online classwork where your name is not shown correctly, and this could be even as minor as putting your first name before your last name (e.g. first name, SURNAME would be INCORRECT and it must be SURNAME, First name). When I sent a kindly-worded email asking why my classwork had been deducted, he sent a really long email reprimanding me for not paying attention to his classwork rules (which by the way do not mention anything about the order of your name). On top of this, he never really fully answers any questions in class (plus he often gets kind of annoyed at students especially when the question is a little more complex), and if you email him with a question, he will literally respond with one-word answers. Lastly, he always seems to be rushing through the material, and he constantly gives you a ton of extra information that is only useful to students who take accounting as their major (which I do not)

Overall, I had a really negative experience with Dennis as my professor over the entire course. Although I was genuinely interested in the material, I found it really hard to concentrate during the lessons because I would be a bit nervous about the classwork which he springs on you every few lectures.

(Please bear in mind that this review might be a bit biased because I really didn't like him or his teaching practices from the beginning of the course, as the 30% deduction thing really annoyed me. Still, I would recommend that you think twice before taking any of his courses.)
reviews.comment_grading:
As I said, I got an -A overall which to be honest I was pretty happy with considering how many marks he took off my classwork.

Although I am happy with my grade, I still think the marking for this course is borderline unethical for the following reasons:

1. He will never let you check how are why you got something wrong in a homework task.
2. Sometimes the classwork asks about topics that we haven't even studied before (and for people who didn't do any accounting at high-school level this is really annoying).
3. The removal of 30% of your grade for not putting your name in his preferred order is perhaps the most ludicrous rule I have ever heard.

Because of all of this, you could really end up with a grade that does not reflect your actual knowledge of the topic.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty standard. You have to do work by yourself because he doesn't actually teach much and expects you to know everything anyway. I will say that the textbook he provided us with was pretty good.

reviews.author: kyddet
reviews.comment_content: Course material is easy for students with accounting background. For those without accounting background, it may be a little difficult at first but you could catch up eventually.
reviews.comment_teaching: Explanation is clear in general. Yet professor sometimes tend to go too fast and ignore the face some students can't really follow. Also, he sometimes can be quite mean and unwilling to fully explain questions students asked.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is relatively fair. Due to the special circumstances this semester, there had been some changes in the grading system, with the final exam taking up a large proportion of the grade. Yet this should only be the case due to the current situation. The original grading system was fair in general.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not much. Originally there were only one midterm and one final exam. Yet due to the special circumstances this year, there had been some in class exercises, mid-term like class practices, take home assignments as well as a final exam. However they were all easy to handle and once again only appeared due to the situation this year.

reviews.author: averychingrocks
reviews.title: Decent course with insane means *FINAL EXAM AND PRACTICE MIDTERMS ATTACHED*
reviews.comment_content:
The content basically covers the very basics of accounting such as the principles and T-accounts, journal entries, construction of the 4 main financial statements and touches upon some slightly more advanced things like bond calculations which are like the pre-requisites and basis of advanced accounting courses should that be your major. Below is the full syllabus.

1. Transactions and the Reporting Process
2. Income Statement, Balance Sheet, Ratios, and Cash Flow Statement
3. Deferred, Prepaid, and Accrued transactions
4. Financial Statement Concepts
5. Even More Transactions and Journal Entries(more complicated)
6. Operating Cycle
7. Revenue Recognition and Fraud
8. Time Value of Money (Important concept for all business courses!!)
9. Contingent Liabilities
10. Bonds 🚩 (Please learn this even if you need to read it more than once... it's completely normal)
11. Stockholders Equity
12. Conservatism Revisited
13. Historical Cost of Asset (NOT ON FINAL)

Content is quite concise and straightforward for the most part. There may be a few red herrings here and there but you should be familiar with everything in the powerpoints for the quiz and final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: Everything tends to be well covered in the extensive powerpoints made for class. If you have any questions, Sidd will ensure that your doubts are cleared. He is a good professor who doesn't bore you to death, maybe given he is quite young. DON'T BE AFRAID TO ASK QUESTIONS. He makes small tiny mistakes in his slides, but feel free to correct him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Better and worse grading system than the other courses at HKUST because no attendance needed but can really screw up your results with one bad grade due to extremely high means.

The weighting system is as follows:
Homeworks = 20% (2 homeworks total, each @ 10%)
First Midterm = 20% (2 hours long)
Second Midterm = 20% (3 hours long)
Final Exam = 40% (48 hour take-home exam due to the special arrangement this semester)

My scores for reference:
Homeworks: Both full (extremely easy as he gave the answers in class)
Midterm 1: 98/100 (Mean: 96.6 and SD: unknown)
Midterm 2: 96/100 (Mean: 92.5 and SD: 6.8)
Final Exam: 170/200 (Mean: 154 and SD: 23) - Crazy online exam and longest 48 hours ever. Most excruciating final I have done so far.
Overall: 92.8% and A-
reviews.comment_workload: Some work to be done especially for the midterms and finals. I got close to 100 for midterm 1 and 2 just by studying 2-3 days before. Homeworks will not take more than a few minutes. However, high workload if you want a very good grade as the means are high.

There are many home works, but the Professor will not check it.

very good grade ar!

reviews.author: boo yay
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concepts and principles of accounting
Textbook: Financial Accounting - Libby, Libby
This course covers most content of the textbook.

The content is interesting and not difficult. I had never studied any business stuff before and I found this course a perfect introduction, giving me a great overview and many basic concepts. Can get good grade without much extra effort as long as you exactly follow the study routine the professor arranged! (Never skip lectures — go to the classroom and stay awake in class, do the assignments and practice quizzes on time, ask questions if you got confused)

Participation: zoom polls (not graded on accuracy but the questions are helpful for testing your understanding)
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are interesting and helpful. TANG Chao is super nice and patient!!!!! He is willing to answer questions though most of my questions are dumb. He cares about the students’ feedback. Love him!!!!!!!

distribution is attached below

reviews.author: Smashgod
reviews.title: See if Professor Chen is the right professor for you (overall comments in "CONTENT")
reviews.comment_content:
An introductory course for accounting that covers the 4 financial statements and how to record different items under different circumstances. I do not like how rigid and strict accounting is so I did not find the course very captivating. The concepts are not difficult to memorize and understand individually but there is a lot to remember in total.

For details on the topics covered, please refer to the attached course syllabus.

My overall comments for this course are as follows: You can safely get a lot of points from group exercises and assignments (also quizzes but depends on how much effort you pay). You should choose her if you only want to secure a decent score. You shouldn't choose her if you want to have a higher chance of getting a high grade (Prof Chen says only a few students got in A-range in her class)
Most suitable for people who have studied accounting before (economics does NOT help at all).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen adopts a blended-learning teaching arrangement, where students watch pre-recorded videos for each chapter (around 15-20 mins) as pre-study at home and she will go through some questions and examples in lessons (which are not compulsory as she claims). It is an acceptable arrangement. However, I think she does not explain enough concepts to students. If you do not have an accounting background (i.e. haven't studied accounting before in high school or somewhere else), this course may be a little tough for you to get on given the rapid pace (details in the 'WORKLOAD" section)

She utilizes the discussion section of Canvas well by setting up a discussion chat for questions to be answered on or before each lesson. She usually answers by directly replying to the Canvas discussion chat. She is responsive and tries her best to leave no questions unanswered (unless she forgot and you have to remind her).

One good thing about Prof. Chen's class is that she gives us a lot of additional exercises to complete (completely optional) so we have plenty of exercises. There is also a Smart Book Reading on McGraw-Hill Connect which can show you the respective concept covered in the question you did from the textbook.

Lessons with quizzes are compulsory. She sets a passcode to access the online quiz so you must be present to get it. Although lessons without quizzes are optional, something troublesome is that Zoom recordings need to be requested if you want to watch them. I attended all lessons so it didn't affect me.

The TA (LEE, Sapere KK) only appeared in one of the pre-study videos and in an announcement or two so we never actually met her. I have no comment for this TA since she is next to non-existent.
reviews.comment_grading:
Interactions and discussions 3%
In-class group exercises (10 sessions) 22%
In-class quizzes (10 quizzes) 30%
Homework assignments (10 assignments) 20%
Final exam 25%

The best part about the grading is that the daily marks take up a large proportion so you can claim a lot of marks here. The final exam takes up a lot less but it really should. Read on to know why.

Interactions and discussions refer to answering questions during lessons and asking questions on Canvas discussion or in lessons. You get the full score by doing any of the above for 4 times.

The content in group exercises is usually 50% in-syllabus and 50% out-syllabus and an article may have to be read. Professor Chen gives you the full mark as long as you finish it and submit it on time (mistakes will not deduct your score).

Quizzes are done on a paid ebook platform called McGraw-Hill Connect (everyone must purchase it for ACCT2010) in closed-book format. Single-chapter quizzes usually consist of 4 MC and/or 'select all appropriate choices' questions. The quiz questions are claimed to be the 'basic' level and they are indeed mostly simple. Comprehensive quizzes have the same format but may include 'numerical response' questions (i.e. filling in the value of a computational question).

Homework assignments are also done on McGraw-Hill Connect. Questions are usually filling in the blanks of financial statements according to the info given. 2 attempts are given so it is in your best interests to ask for all correct computational methods before your final attempt (everyone has the same questions but different numerical data).

The final exam... is NOTHING LIKE THE usual quizzes and homework. It is split into 3 parts: basic, intermediate, and advanced. 'Basic' was 30 marks, 'Intermediate' was 76 marks, and 'Advanced' was 42 marks. The intermediate part was already too overwhelming for us since what we usually do are the basic-level questions. We were allowed to bring in 8-pages of cheat sheets, but even with them the final exam is a guaranteed FAIL. The same also occurs to students who get full marks in the quizzes. I hope Prof. Chen keeps her word and only allocates 25% to the final exam.

There is a choice for us to shift at most 7% of our quiz scores to the final exam. Still, the decision has to be made before the final exam. After experiencing the final exam, I can say with certainty that you mustn't do that since your final may well be a disaster.

All in all, the grading is decent if the final exam does not take up any more than 25%, so I will give it a B.

The results for the final exam are unknown (in her latest announcement about our grade, she said 'The final exam grades will not be released in order to avoid unnecessary panic') but I know I got a B+ for my grade. You are recommended to refer to the Word file I attached which is the 'final exam' announcement from Prof. Chen to get a better idea of the grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
The pace of this course is the most rapid out of all courses I took in my Year 1 fall semester.

Around 1 chapter has to be COMPLETED in 1 week (2 lessons). 1 group exercise, 1 assignment, and 1 quiz have to be finished in each chapter, then the next one starts immediately.

The workload is manageable but I find the pace a little too fast. You have a consistent practice for ACCT2010 throughout the term if you prepare for quizzes seriously (then again, all my hard work didn't seem to be very effective in the final exam)

All the extra exercises give us plenty of chances for practicing the basic-level questions.

reviews.author: selfdeprecation
reviews.title: Introductory Course on Accounting
reviews.comment_content: The course covers basic concepts on accounting, including double-entry accounting, accrual accounting, financial statements, and simple journal entries.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mak Daddy's teaching style appeals to those who have studied accounting before. His lectures feel like a discussion of accounting and accounting related topics, and he expects students to learn the material before coming to class.

His powerpoints are very good and cover the contents of the whole course. You do not miss out on much by skipping the lectures and there is no need to review the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
35% online assignments - multiple choice and problem solving
20% midterm - multiple choice, one extended response
45% final - multiple choice and extended response

The final is not cumulative, meaning topics tested during the midterm will NOT appear on the final. It's important to note that you must purchase access to the online textbook in order to attempt the online assignments, lest you lose out on 35% of your grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is reasonable, with 7 online assignments, 1 midterm, and 1 final. The online assignments are quite easy but Mak Daddy insists on giving his students one attempt and one attempt only, so make sure you do well on them.

reviews.author: Peanutrice
reviews.title: course for bba students
reviews.comment_content: studying fundimental accounting knowledge like trail balance, balance and p and L

great prof with impressive excel skills
but taught a bit too fast

Tbh the exam is pretty hard but easy to get a good grade.

have assignment after every section. Not very hard but the word load is huge.

Also theres a tutorial section every week.

I think the quizzes are easy to get high mark (like 6.75/7.5). But the final is very difficult (open book for my term). I guess the questions will be easier for closed book.

I got A- at last (i had studied BAFS in high school) and my friend got A at last(she had studied BAFS and ECON in high school). I think the grading is mostly good for students with Accounting background. But my another friend who did not study BAFS got B+. I think you need to work very hard (memorize all the concepts) to get good grade if you do not know Accounting.

I did enjoy some parts of it, and the knowledge I got from this course was applied later on in FINA 2303 etc. I had not taken any accounting classes before coming to UST but the content wasn't confusing to an extreme extent.

One time I used a friend’s computer to log in to Zoom and he scolded me using tons of emails because he thought that I was cheating wth. He is really harsh and his lessons are really boring. reviews.author: 天水圍陳奕迅
reviews.title: Good intro accounting course
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen teaching is great.
She is willing to answer everyones question immediately no matter in class or after class. She encourages people to raise questions on canvas. She will reply all those questions very quickly.

reviews.author: Mivy Wenceslas
reviews.title: Bad Teaching but Excellent Class
reviews.comment_content:
1. Financial accounting around us
2. Balance sheet
3. Income Statement
4. Year end adjustments
5. Sales revenue + receivable
6. Property, plant and equipment
7. Liabilities
8. Owners equity
9. Cash flows

The syllabus in comparison with other accounting courses is drastically shorter. Corporate bonds, Present value and Quality of Cash Flows etc. are not included. Hence, people, especially with prior accounting knowledge, have significant advantage in this course. However, the easier content also enables people new to accounting to catch up very easily. I would say that people who want to take up an accounting major may better seek another professor, since Kelvin Mak teaches really limited content with his efficiency and quality.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This Professor has several big issues in teachings.

1. His time allocation in teaching various topics is a failure. He spends about 3 weeks on the very basics of accounting. However, he rushed through the last chapters which should be considerably harder, thus will easily confuse students.

2. His teachings is very inefficient. He always introduces new things even when he is teaching the basics in the beginning, thus it takes 3 weeks for the first two topics. For example, he suddenly introduces accruals when talking about chapter 2, when accruals are supposed to be chapter 3. Also, he talks a lot on irrelevant knowledge for the exam and also repeats several times every lesson. This pointless teachings along with lame annotations made his teaching dull and pointless. In fact, I skipped most of the lessons.

3. He does not answer questions that much. Granted, he does answer questions in the lecture. However, there is one time when I send an email to him about my enquiries in chapter 12 (Cash Flow), the most recent topic, he neglected the email TWICE COMPLETELY. This is really ironic and intentional since not only I sent it twice, but I also got an immediate response right when I sent an email concerning about the exam format. This shows he is not really a reliable teacher that will answer every question.

To give him some credits, He does provide extra lesson for those new to accounting. But still, he is bad in teaching and will confuse many of the new-to-accounting students. Basically, the mean mark of the mid-term shows his teachings.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 35%
Mid-term  25%
Final 40%

It counts the best 7 out of 8 assignments, each @5%. While the first 5 have unlimited attempts and guarantee full marks, the last 3 only has one attempt along with occasional hints. To be fair, the assignments are probably harder than the Mid-term.

Mid-term exam is incredibly easy. It consists of mostly very basic questions. To be honest, the mean should be higher if he could teach better, but many people are getting confused by his teachings.

Since the final mark is still not publicized, I will only give some of my insights. The final for some reason addresses the questions topic-by-topic, starting from the last chapters to the first chapters in the exam syllabus (Note: The exam syllabus is not cumulative, from bad debts to cash flows) It is not particularly difficult but definitely harder than the Mid-term. There is much less time given to do the MCs while too much time for the LQs. In my experience, I have around 15 minutes left with the MCs but I have quite a number of them being uncertain. For LQs, I pretty much sat for an hour just waiting for the exam to end.

Assignments: Full Mark
Mid-term: 236/240 (Mean:192)
Final: Unknown
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely light workload.
Only 8 assignments in general. Expect around 40-90 minutes for each assignment depending on your ability.
I would say this course has the least workload out of all my other courses.
Basically, I rarely attended lessons and only did the 8 assignments. Also did some exercises in the textbook just before the exams (He provided all textbook answers) and it turned out fine.

reviews.author: eprrr
reviews.comment_content:
I put the scope of ACCT 2010 in the attachment. It is a must course for b&m school students. I have little to say about the content. It is about the 4 financial statement. First 2 months is mainly focusing on balance sheet and income statement. Last month would be cash flow statement with the help of the first 2.
A reminder: you need to understand the logic behind to avoid challenging questions. rote leaning is not suitable for you
reviews.comment_teaching:
Boring but passionated.
Once I ask him so many questions through email, I thought he will reply me one by one. Instead of replying it one by one, he reserved a 1-to-1 zoom session for me at Sunday to answer my questions alongside providing me some sugesstions. It is rare in ust.
You must go to his lesson as it counts participation. I have to admit that I hate him at first as his lecture notes is not enough for you to understand what he said. You have to read the book yourself to follow him on lesson.
He tried to teach well but the scope does not allow. It is better to read yourself and watch back video if you don't understand. However, I do not encourage you to just use browser on lesson. Just try to understand what he said on lesson, maybe you can understand, he isn't that bad, just a dull tone.
reviews.comment_grading:
As of now, I still haven't receive my final result. But I got an A-. I would not say it is good grade, but rather how hard you work how much you gain. I will explain my thought in below.
(Again see attachment for detail information)
My result:
Test 1: 167.55 / 200 (mean: 170; sd: 29.20)
Test 2: 238.85 / 270 (mean: 78.38% ; StDev: 14.85%)
Test 3: 299.2 / 300 (mean: 87% ; 14%)
Final: rot yet released

Terry puts all hard homework questions as test and final problems, not even changing the number. Only a very few of the questions (i.e. 2 out of 30) are new questions, but they are not hard if you understand the other questions well. You can get a very nice grade even you have not study acct before. I am a non-bafs student and I stop study econ or math for one year b/c I chose retake. Even so, you can see my mark is progressing after every test.
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely heavy, as I give D even I get A-

Reason for saying workload is heavy.
It is easy to see that it is heavy without comparison. 1) The total mark for all homework is 3330 and there are nearly 300 questions (including sub questions).
2) All questions are either hard or very hard. For concept questions, you must understand the whole session to get it correct. For factual questions, you at least have to read through the whole page to get the correct answer, sometimes you even need to click on the attachment or appendix to get the right answers.
3) Time is limited: Not that you are required to finish in few hours, but the total time allowed for one assignment is short. In other first year course, you have 2 weeks to finish one assignment. It is, however, not for terry's students. As he decide to put assignment after add/drop period, most assignment have to be finished in a rush. Usually 2 weeks for 2 assignment and the later one usually have 1 week only as he haven't teach. The last 3 assignments are crammed in 2 weeks. It is tough to finish it.
4) You cannot copy from internet: As aforementioned, he put homework questions in test. As a result, you need to digest it even you copy from chegg or course hero. It is more beneficial to do it yourself in my view.
5) Only 3 try. It is so different from other course and very pressured. You can understand it easily as homework accounts for 24% total mark as well as your test mark. I remember the mean for homework is 89 - 90% (not sure as he accidentally showed on lecture). You cannot form a team b/c u won't get any classmates help on zoom as he blocked the chat and there is no discussion time.
6) There are MC and long questions for homework. Long question is not easy than MC. Long questions are basically requiring you to do all the things you learnt and did in MC again. He wants to check your understanding. And some long questions are challenging that you can finish with book but not without book, which means you should revise them during the period you do homework.

Period for 1 homework:
Minimum: 5 hour
Longest: 10 hour
Average: 7 hour
(It takes so long as I learnt while doing it as mentioned, I asked my acct friends and she said she tooks 3 hours for early chapter)

Homework is one important factor that make its workload so heavy, but not the only one. Another one is practice questions.
Practice questions are very similar to homework. Terry will release homework first and then release answer for practice questions. Practice questions are after-book exercises. Those difficult after-book questions are your homework. If you want to get full in homework, you may want to do practice questions first and then use the method to check your homwork. It takes much lower time to finish practice problem as there are no MCs.
P.S. last chapter practice questions = final long questions.

Would I say workload is heavy? Definitely. But is it such bad? No. You can learn much more than other class and you can control your grade by your effort.

Recommedation:
1) not clever but willing to paid
2) clever and willing to paid
3) want to experience the felling of an accounting student

reviews.author: cancan
reviews.title: Excellent course to start your uni life
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite simple if you had taken BAFS in secondary school but you won't have much of a disadvantage if you didn't take accounting before since it's quite easy to catch up!

However, the final is far harder than the HW quizzes and midterm (which are quite easy since they are almost the same as the example questions)  so I strongly recommend you to look at the slides carefully even though it seems that there's not much important in some of the slides if you're a high-achiever, but some difficult questions involve points from real-life statements and articles, which I'm sure most would skip through.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite interesting and lively. He would use real-life examples like movies to illustrate the content and financial statements of mega-corporations, which makes it easier to understand the content. Strongly suggest you attend his lectures if possible since he occasionally talks about useful points for your assignments and tests.

His lecture notes are well-arranged so it's easy for us to find the key points of the chapter albeit there might be a lot of slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very lenient. He gave us 50-60% of the marks in some questions in the final we had answered incorrectly as long as we had attempted them. He also provided us answers for the HW quizzes with adequate explanations so we can understand the concepts a lot better if you didn't at first.

HW Quizzes: 30%
Midterm:30%
Final:40%
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light. We had 60 hours to finish 3 HW Quizzes ( almost 1 per month), which aren't even that long, and 72 hours to finish our midterm. But we had to finish our final within 3 hours like other courses. The workload is very manageable as long as you're not a deadline fighter.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: Best professor ever
reviews.comment_content:
Financial Accounting
Class 1: overview
Class 2: Financial Statements
Class 3 4: Transactions and the reporting process
Class 5 6: Income Statement, Balance Sheet, Ratios and Cash Flow Statement
Class 7: Deferred, Prepaid and Accrued transactions
Class 8: Financial Statement Concepts
Class 9 10: Example 2 Journal Entries
Class 11 12: More detailed in contents of Class 5 6
Class 12 13: Other Journal Entries
Class 14: Operating Cycles
Class 15: Revenue Recognition
Class 16**: Time Value Loans
Class 17: Liabilities
Class 18 19**: Bonds
Class 20: Equity
Class 21: Conservatism
(For the topics with ** requires more math understanding)

I do not have any accounting background and still manage to catch up all the things in class. Be hardworking and spend more time on those things you thought is trivial. It is because time is the key in the exam. If you can finish all basic things without thinking a lot, you are more likely to get high marks.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sidd is the best professor I have ever seen so far in HKUST.
He taught so many things other than accounting. Like he shared his own experiences and different ways of learning.

He likes to put more real-life example which makes the class less boring. You can have a basic idea of how companies in the real world is performing, why they are making different decisions and those frauds :) ... and these should be the most valuable takeaway from this course. I am very into it.

He is also lenient on grading. In homework quizzes or exams, there always will be different answer sets for the same questions. Even you cannot get the correct answer, he still gives you majority of the marks given that you have written something meaningful :D

His teaching is base on something called top-down approach. That is give the big picture first, then refines every detail (which is not suitable for me). Therefore, it is not a big problem if you don't know what he is talking about. You can ask him (he answer any kinds of questions) or wait until he gives detailed explanation.

Good English, Excellent in explaining contents. Humble and nice guy :D
reviews.comment_grading:
15% higher of quiz 1/quiz 2 = 15/15
15% quiz 3 =14/15
30% Midterm = 30/30 (median: 100/100)
40% Final = 80.5/100 = 32.2/40 (mean: 57.2, highest: 96/100)

Overall 91.2/100 Grade: A
Thank you so much Sidd...I can't imagine I can get an A when competing with so many other students with accounting background ;)


The midterm is super easy as it is same as the format of what is taught in lectures. Therefore nearly everyone gets 100.

The final exam is super lengthy and hard since it is online exam. Sidd used to give take-home exam but this is banned by SBM this year. Therefore, he made it super lengthy and hard to differentiate students. Be prepared for his final :)
reviews.comment_workload:
No attendance. I know there are other sessions that take attendance.
Only 3 hw quizzes and their difficulty is not high (everything can be found in lecture notes).
Midterm is 24-hours take-home exam. (open everything)
Final is 3 hours exam with 2 parts (open everything). Actually all materials examined in midterm and final can be founded in lecture notes. However, for the final exam, you do not have time to find the contents. It will be good if you can remember all the things/create a cheatsheet/excel template for all the things.

Sidd gives practice examples before midterm and final. Should do them before the final and count how many time you used :)

reviews.author: klgayau
reviews.title: Good Professor!
reviews.comment_content:

Prof. Tang 好nice同埋教書都幾好，會歸納學生係midterm或者功課唔識既部分上堂解釋多次。落堂之後都好歡迎學生問佢問題，解答得好詳盡，係好有心既professor
