reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is very nice.
easy to follow but watch the lectures bc he usually takes notes on the ppt and most of the times it's not included in the ppt he uploads.
reviews.comment_grading: the exam was meh bc it was closed and required a lot of content to memorize.
reviews.comment_workload: Not a lot of workload. McGraw Hill homework questions every chapter. The quizzes and exams are also tested on McGraw Hill website.

reviews.author: AmanJ
reviews.title: Pretty good, if you get Sidd
reviews.comment_content: The content is moderately interesting, it's easy enough for the first few weeks that you can practically not attend class and still be fine, but the difficulty picks up very rapidly after the midterm and this translates to a difficult exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof is really good, he is very welcoming of students and he always takes the time to answer every question quite thoroughly. And he puts in effort to make his classes more interesting, solid guy right here.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading as a whole is pretty lenient, the prof and TA are quite willing to accept small errors as right answers too. They're also pretty fast in marking assignments and the exams too.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments and quizzes are regarded as the same items in this course with Sidd, and there are 3 "Homework Quizzes" as he calls them. They're spaced out mostly evenly through the semester and the first 2 are easy, the third one is difficult.

The midterm was based entirely on the first Homework Quiz, and is quite easy to ace. (Sidd said that nearly the entire class gets 100%). The final exam is very difficult by design, and could be really troublesome.

reviews.author: JNC
reviews.title: Professor is super nice
reviews.comment_content:
50% DSE content + something new
will be quite difficult for students who never learnt accounting before.

reviews.comment_grading:
fair.
I have studied bafs before so I only did very light revision for quizzes and exams. B+ at the end.
reviews.comment_workload: quite heavy compared to other business courses. many assignments but they are not based on accuracy so take you time. quizzes are also quite frequent, but are useful for  studies.

reviews.author: 涵x
reviews.comment_content: Basic knowledge about accounting, especially for finical statement.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is very nice but the teaching is poor. If i don't preview the course, i can't understand a single one concept since i am a totally beginner in accounting.

Quiz (4)
Assignment (best 8)
Final

The grade is very very competitive!!!
For quiz, mean+1sd is often above full mark. Final is easy so the mark may also frightening.
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment for each chapter
First few assignments took me about 4 hours each but later one are much more easier.

reviews.author: yoyo.y
reviews.comment_content:
Financial accounting chapter 1- 4, 6-12

She gives explanations and answers all the questions from the assiginment and ppt during the lessons and on the canvas.

-In-class discussions and exercises: 25%
-In-class quizzes: 30%
-Homework assignments(10 assignments for each chapter): 20%

reviews.author: winner
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
In class, he talks some materials not covered in textbook(will not be tested, useful & interesting for me).
a little bit impatient and bad tempered. I'm sort of afraid to email him.
very strict to submission. 30% discount for writing name or showing name in zoom not in the order as he expected
reviews.comment_grading:
Classworks (numerous) 30%
Homework assignments (3) 40%
Final assessment (1) 30%
Around 9 classworks, full mark varies from 5-10. I usually got 70% correct. If I reviewed slides before classwork, I got nearly 90% correct. It's not that hard, I think.

(sorry that I only remember a rough percentage score )
reviews.comment_workload:
though we didn't have midterm, assignments took me some time. workload for assignments is heavy

reviews.author: HKUST-er
reviews.title: Easy Course For BAFS Students
reviews.comment_content:
Basic accounting principles, simpler than HKDSE BAFS curriculum, but be careful that there are some difference in handling some transactions and the account name as well.

Please remember to buy the textbook with Connect access. It is a must as this platform will be used in quizzes, assignments and exam!
reviews.comment_teaching: A very nice professor. Blended learning mode is used in her lectures. She will upload some lecture videos (~30 mins per week), and the lecture are Q&A sessions or discussion + quiz session. The attendance for Q&A sessions are optional.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
25% In-class discussions and exercises
-10 sessions, full marks as long as you attended the session)

30% In-class quizzes
-10 quizzes, 8 of them are in form of simple MC questions (usually 3) on a specific chapter (each takes up 2% of total weight), 2 of them are comprehensive quiz with MCs and short questions with numerical answer (they cover Chaps.1-4 and 6-8 respectively, and each takes up 7% of total weight).

20% Homework assignments
-10 assignments, each corresponds to one chapter, and the marks of the assignments will be converted to the final mark. The allowed attempt for the assignment will be reduce after few chapters, so read the instruction carefully. The assignments are done on Connect platform and the questions are from the textbooks and professor provides answers to the question in textbook as well (but be careful that the numbers will be different). Professor will also teach how to do the assignments in the Q&A sessions, and on the discussion corner in Canvas.

25% Final exam
Final exam will be significantly harder than the previous quiz, but it's still MCs and numerical answers.

It is possible to "transfer" not more than 9% weight (that is, four small quiz, or one small quiz and one comprehensive quiz) in in-class quizzes to final exam (i.e. use the mark in final exam to replace the mark in quiz(zes) when calculating the final score) before the final exam, but DO NOT do so unless you missed a quiz and got 0 or you completely messed up the quiz, as the final exam is significantly harder than the quiz, so transferring the weight will just lower your final score in most circumstances.
reviews.comment_workload:
Watch lecture videos (~30 mins per week)
Do homework assignments (10 in total)
Attend discussion + quiz session (10 in total)
Revision for the exam
That's all.

reviews.author: parttimestudent
reviews.comment_content:
All topics in this course are covered in HKDSE BAFS. If you have taken that no need to worry about the content.
but if you are new to accounting, the content of this course are quite easy to understand, no need to worry about that too:)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dennis is an HK prof, with a good English accent. and he is willing to answer your questions after class time. you can even ask him in Cantonese.
Yet, his teaching speed is relatively fast. if you don't have any accounting knowledge before, you may spend more time on revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
quite competitive ;
students with accounting background have a great advantage
reviews.comment_workload:
little;
some easy classwork every lesson
1-2 assignment

reviews.author: 爛grade人士
reviews.title: Actually I think he's not too bad as I think (you can choose him)
reviews.comment_content:
It includes assignments (12 in total) around 30%, 3 tests (so not really a mid-year exam) total 40% and a final exam 20% (not sure), and it calculates attendance need you to open the webcam during class.

He gives us three tries in our assignment (in connect) and if you be careful you can get it all correct. The 3 tests and final exams are based on the assignments he gave, so if you want to get a good grade, remember to mark down tricky questions and revise more.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall it's okay but his talking speed is somehow slow so if you're not good at understanding English, this professor is recommended. He's willing to answer questions in class and email (but must use ITSC email) but not really quick reply. Other factors such as whether you know what he's talking, is really really okay but frankly speaking if you don't concentrate you will not know what he's saying. Don't worry, lecture recording is provided.
reviews.comment_grading: I got a good grade in ACCT2010, i.e. A, because I studied ACCT in secondary school, got a basic idea of what's going on :) If you're hardworking and study through his PowerPoint and the book, you will get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Actually it's quite a big workload as he accumulated two to three homework in the same deadline (with test), so if you are a deadline fighter remember to be aware of it. As I'm not, I think it's okay and I have studied ACCT in my secondary school.

reviews.author: Anth
reviews.comment_content:
Not necessary to look at the lecture slides without listening to the lectures as he mentioned and wrote down numerous perspectives and answers during class which sometimes were skipped in the recording
The final exam was fine as the syllabus only focused on the last few chapters, but there are many conceptual questions which requires comprehensive understanding towards the whole topic instead of knowing the answering technique. Even you got Lv5 or above in DSE, you might lose some score in those definition questions.
In the positive sides, he applied lots of sample questions and examples to enhance our knowledge and answering flow in every topic.
reviews.comment_teaching: He included various real-life example into his lectures which strengthen our standing towards the whole concept, however he is autocratic to a certain extent. For example, some students would like to ask further questions or raise a queries during class but he would neglect or blame on them due to lecture interruption. He would rarely answer the email properly, especially towards grade or marking enquiries.
reviews.comment_grading:
Relatively straightforward but if the name in zoom was in the wrong format, he will deduct 30% of the mark, which seems quite harsh as someone would type their surname at the back.
The classwork is based on Connect so there's a model answer, but the homework is a bit challenging, therefore the s.d is relatively high.
He didn't release the final grading but the grade distribution seems to be fair.
Grading:
30% Classwork
40% Homework
30% Final exam
B-
reviews.comment_workload:
Relatively light
Despite the 3 pieces of homework are complicated and divided into many small parts, the difficulty is appropriate for students if they did basic revision

reviews.author: CCM_T13
reviews.title: Plz cherish the opportunity of being taught by her
reviews.comment_content:
There are two types of lessons inside this course, lessons with Q&A section and lessons with quiz.For the former ones, no attendence
is counted and just feel free to attend these lessons. For the latter ones, of coz u need to attend for those quizzes, attendence still will not counted but u will lose that proportion of marks. But before quiz time, there are group classworks which are also included in the calculation of your result. These quizzes and grp assignments should not be missed as the final will be much harder if u don't even take quizzes. The second reason is of coz these will at least secure a part of your marks.
reviews.comment_teaching: Thoroughly. Even though I had BAFS in my sec school life, some terms are different but financial statements are pretty much the same, there are a lots of new things. If u want to skip lessons, u can skip the lessons with Q&A sections on the first two months, but u still need to study hard for quizzes.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is no mid-term but quite a lot of quizzes, around 1 per week. However, the quizzes are easy, a lot pf them only consist of 3-5 mc questions. Comprehensive quizzes are more difficult but not too much.
Final, ugh, much more difficult, a whole different level comparing with comprehensive quizzes. But it can separate people that know thoroughly and people that cheat in quizzes or use three to four hours for a homework in order to get a full mark.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is a bit large. It's not very difficult but need to focus doing homework in order to get a high mark. The mean is quite high, around 3-5 marks below full mark. But these homework is REALLY important because similar things will appear in comprehensive quizzes.

reviews.author: Jason~
reviews.title: Short summary
reviews.comment_content: The content overall is not hard or challenging but it takes a considerable amount of time to study. Plus, it has test almost bi-weekly which counts towards the final grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is alright it’s just me who can not quit grasp the idea of everything and I’ll have to take extra time to understand everything. Probably because of the presumption that students in the class already have an accounting background he taught quite quickly which can be challenging for some.

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy as the homework only come once a week.

Powerful Grade

reviews.author: yhleeak
reviews.title: passionate professor
reviews.comment_content: fundamentals of accounting concepts like the 4 financial statements, asset+ stockholders equity= liability, etc. as u may need to compete with those people who studied bafs in high school, which have essentially the same content with this course, for people who didn't (like me) may need to pay extra effort in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: the professor is very passionate about teaching and nice as well, so if ur in his lectures I highly recommend u to pay attention to his teaching, as he will do a lot of class practices with u and help u build a strong foundation of accounting knowledges so that u can spend much less effort for the final. there are also homework and quizzes to help u catch up with the class. attendence is counted in this class.
reviews.comment_grading: the grading is fine as sbm started to adapt absolute grading instead of curved this sem. but since absolute grading is adapted, it is even more important to try ur best to score full mark on all quizzes and hw as it may save u in case u fked up ur final. for me, as most of my hws are full mark and quizzes are much above mean, even though i only get like 3x/100 in final i still managed to get a B.
reviews.comment_workload: workload is pretty large as for this professor he will give u >=1hw every week and quizzes per 2wk. and ur likely to fk up ur quizzes if u dun study for it, which may largely affect ur final grade cuz it is absolute grading.

reviews.author: aict
reviews.title: Quite good grade
reviews.comment_content: Basic financial accounting including four financial statements, calculation of bad debts, depreciation and bonds. Relatively simple and not unmanageable as long as you understand the working principles.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is very willing to answer and elaborate on questions, as well as allowing us to ask questions about homework and the quizzes. There are specific office hours or Q&A sessions after class so feel free to ask him any hypothetical or conceptual questions. There are potential misunderstandings so be specific when asking a question or else he may go off a tangent in the wrong direction.

His powerpoint is not really sufficient for understanding the material so preview the textbook instead. Speaking from my own experience as a student without any background knowledge in business, it is easier to understand the content as it is more thorough in explanation and easier to follow. The slides are practically useless. Attendance is required so you have to attend class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade!
Marking Scheme:
Class participation 6% Not released
HW 24% Full marks
Test 1 10% 200/200 (100%)
Test 2 15% 254.9/270 (94.41%)
Test 3 15% 290/230 (96.67%)
Final Exam 30% Not released
Final Grade A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Not sure how he grades participation, but I attended all of his lectures and turned my camera on for most of them as well as asked questions in the Q&A sessions. I didn't speak up much in class so I guess it wasn't a large factor in grading.

I did preview and make notes for the whole semester, it is quite time-consuming for students without financial knowledge to understand everything from scratch, but building a good foundation in the early few weeks helps you immensely in grasping more difficult concepts.

The homework is quite difficult. You get three tries in each assignment and it counts the last try as your final mark. For most of the assignments I finished in 1-2.5 hours, but sometimes it took me 3-4 hours depending on my level of understanding.

The practice questions are useful in helping you understand concepts used in the homework as they are similar. As quizzes and exams have similar questions to the homework, make sure you understand the questions in homework and also do all if not most practice questions.

Only the final exam requires you to write on paper. It is divided into two parts, part one on connect and part two on canvas. Part two is written and only examines the last few chapters. You are also allowed to bring in a cheat sheet. Pay attention for the long questions in the practice questions, it is likely that the final contains questions requiring you to answer in the same pattern.

reviews.author: meowk
reviews.comment_content:
Basic accounting course, just an introduction or a quick review of your high school BAFS. Some concepts are different as the accounting systems are different.

It will be easy if you have studied accounting before, or have learned some of it. Not hard to understand if you pay attention during lessons and ask questions whenever you have any.
reviews.comment_teaching: A bit bored but teaching is pretty well, just pronounced few words with a special accent, lol. Tbh, if you haven't learned accounting in your highschool, it could be hard to understand if you do not pay attention. However, if you have learned it before, you feel bored listening to that. Not so recommended if you're new to accounting cuz it will be hard to catch up, but at the end of the day, you just need to put some more effort. He's willing to answer your questions after lesson or even sending him emails, so you could ask as much as you like to.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading.

1 SD above in final gives you an A, along with finishing assignments and attending all lessons.

With online teaching this semester makes your participation marks easier to get, all you need to do is to answer the polling questions on zoom. It doesn't matter if you get the correct answer or not, voting counts and it is not hard to achieve full marks in attendance.

There's unlimited attempts in most of the assignments so you can just try your best to finish all of them. Not that hard.
reviews.comment_workload:
Easy. One quiz on connect every 2 weeks and just study beforehand, everything you need to answer is in the lecture handouts and powerpoint slides. SmartBook assignments with unlimited attempts and problem sets.

No midterm, just regular quizzes and assignments plus the final exam.

reviews.author: myeeeee
reviews.comment_content:
You can learn a lot basic accounting knowledge in this course. For me, a non business school student, I learn  much in it.
2 Financial Statement
3 T-Accounts and Journal Entries
4 T-Accounts and Journal Entries
5,6 Creating the Balance Sheet, Income Statement, Cash Flow Statement, and Ratios
7 Matching Principle

9, 10 Sales Revenue, Receivables, and Cash (Bad debt expense, credit sales, uncollectable receivables)

reviews.comment_teaching: The professor taught in a easily understanding way with clearly explanation and example. Besides, the professor will take some companies as an example to let us know how it work in reality world The professor English pronunciation is  great and it is easy to understand what the class is going on. Power point is clear and easy to read.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW 1 and 2(chose the highest one) 15%
HW 3 15%
Midterm 30%
Final 40 %

I get 15% on HW 1 and 2
11.75% on HW3
95/100 on midterm (most people got 100)
78 on final which average is around 57 and SD is about 20.
I got A- , I think it is not hard to get high grade.
reviews.comment_workload: just three HW in semester, it take about half a day to finish one. Professor will give some example question and you can do it after class for practicing.

reviews.author: Starstriker
reviews.title: fair grade with tons of workload. Watch out
reviews.comment_content: There are tons of topic being covered in his course. Make sure get rid of his course. The syllabus of the finals was horrible as it is all the stuff you have learnt in this sem

reviews.author: Alex1
reviews.comment_content: Content is fairly straightforward from the online textbook and practice exercises.
reviews.comment_teaching: Do not go to her Q&A lectures. They are a waste of time. I would have been much more prepared if I used that time to study the textbook myself.
reviews.comment_grading: Very fair grading. Although the course is rather hard, the grades usually reflect effort throughout the class. 40% C 40% B and 20% A.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework and quizzes due about every 10 days. Better to study throughout the semester in order to do well on weekly quizzes. Lots of review is needed for the final.

reviews.author: 千金難買老娘樂意
reviews.comment_content: Too lazy to copy and paste
reviews.comment_teaching: She is a really nice professor cuz she would answer all sorts of questions and is very efficient when it comes to replying to emails. You can tell that she puts in the effort to make the course more fun and interesting. I don't know if this is the case for everyone but for me, all of Prof Chen's ACCT2010 courses are in blended-learning mode, which means that you have to watch some pre-recorded videos before the lecture. Instead of teaching the actually course content during the lecture, we are suppose to watch all the videos before class (in which I totally didn't do). Prof Chen will answer your questions and give you a brief summary about last week's stuff. If you ever have any questions, just ask her. She uses her email like Whatsapp.
reviews.comment_grading:
Before I go into detail, my dumbass got a mere C+ in this course. I did DSE, but I did not study BAFS. I think that if you DO NOT have any prior knowledge in accounting, DO NOT choose blended learning mode. Some of the videos are very simple and for a starter it is very harder to catch up. Just trust me, blended learning is not for you dear.

The second thing is, my lecture (specifically L14) was full of WBB students. If you don't know what WBB is, just think of them as overpowered year 2 students from all across the globe. Not only are they elites, they also dominate all the quizzes and assignments. If you see a absurd amount of foreign students in your class then you know what to do, swap OUT of this lecture cuz its gonna be a blood bath.

Tbh if you think you are a strong student you will find it an easy course with not much new to learn but literally everyone gets full marks in everything so you better watch out for the careless mistakes.

Although I kinda caught up with everyone before finals and scored 0.33 sd above mean, I still got a C+ cuz my quizzes and assignments were miserable.
reviews.comment_workload: For a slow learning student who was definitely not meant to study business, I think having to catch up with others is already very hard. To make matters worse, Prof Chen covers one chapter a week. Each chapter has an assignment, a quiz and a group discussion. The group discussion is fine. Just open your mouth and say something. It doesnt have to be value-adding. The quizzes are simple as they are mostly 3-5 MCQs, but for a dumbass like me i usually get 2 out of 3 while the entire class gets 3. The assignments are the worse, Especially for the first few assignments, they are long and hard (thats what she said) for a student with no accounting background like me. Prof Chen literally emailed me asking me why I opened my assignment for 54 hours. Well thats becuz its so hard I couldn't finish it in one day, so i left it open over night and continued the next morning. Remember the situation happens every week cuz 1 assignment 1 chapter.

reviews.author: Colemanlol
reviews.title: Nice Professor! Really so good!
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the content is similar to BAFS DSE syllabus
Some are new , like cash flow statement, Contingent liabilities...
But it is not that hard.
Though you have not studied BAFS in secondary school, you can still understand the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Basically Professor Sidd is so good. He explains the content in detail. Also, when you ask questions related to the content, he will answer all of the questions, so you can handle the content well.
He is a passionate and nice teacher.
For mid term, we have around 3 days to do, so you can do it easily.
While for final, we have 3 hours to do 2 parts.
I would really recommend to choose him if you take ACCT2010.
Also if you email him and ask him questions, he usually replies you quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW1/HW2 15% (Choose the best one)
HW3 15%
Mid Term 30%
Final 40%

HW1: 8.25/10
HW2: 15/15
HW3: 13/15
Mid Term: 100/100 ( mean : ~95)
Final: 80/100 (mean: 57.2, highest 96)
Overall grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
Only 3 HW, Mid term and Final
Though for HW3, it takes a bit time but is still not too hard.
He will give you a similar self-practice to you before doing the homework and exams, so you can familiarize the format before doing homework/taking exams.

reviews.author: poiuy
reviews.title: Choose Dennis if you took BAFS (Accounting) in secondary school
reviews.comment_content:
Almost half of the course has already been taught in the DSE syllabus so it would be an advantage for those who took BAFS(Accounting) in secondary school. Another half are something new that wasn't so difficult to catch up with.
Whole course grade = Classwork (30%) + Assignments 1-3 (30%) + Final (40%)
Beware that random quizzes aka classwork may pop up at the end of some lessons (so far I got 8/9 :/). If a classwork's content was about what he taught last lesson, accuracy will be counted; for classwork covering topics he taught that lesson, only efforts will be counted. Noted that the classwork mark will only be given if a full attendance of that lesson was recorded.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although Dennis spoke and taught in a pretty quick speed, he truly taught well by providing many details and examples to help us understood every topic. Concentrate during his lessons or you would miss a lot.  Kind reminder: REMEMBER TO FOLLOW HIS GUIDELINES FOR BOTH CLASSWORK AND ASSIGNMENTS e.g. signing the academic declaration in his required format, put you surname before your first name when doing classwork on zoom, switch on your camera when doing classwork etc. OR YOU WILL FACE HEAVY MARK DEDUCTION!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal grades.
For reference, I got an A-, mark distribution as follows:
Classwork: I got at least 50% in every classwork only 1 or 2 were full mark as I remember.
3 Assignments: all above mean 1 SD or above
Final: not revealed
Remember to revise for classwork, do assignments carefully and prepare well for final, then you will survive.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much work to do. Dennis required us to complete 3 assignments in total (each had around 1-2 week to complete). It is good that topics covered in each assignment is not accumulative e.g. Assignment 1 covered Ch. 1-3, Assignment 2 covered Ch. 4-6 etc. Most importantly, the content of the final exam was not accumulative as well, I just had to revise the last few chapters.

reviews.author: yr1
reviews.title: Easy course for student with BAFS background
reviews.comment_content: This course includes some basic concept of accounting. Some of the topics are same or similar to some content in the dse syllabus so it should be easy for students who studied BAFS. Knowing some general principle of accounting certainly helps.
reviews.comment_teaching: Terry is nice and he always answer our questions. He have a Q&A zoom session every week. He will answer zoom inbox questions during the lesson and share his response to the whole class. However, it may be a bit challenging for students with no BAFS background to catch up as some concept are implied in the teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is the following

Class Participation   6%
Homework              24%
Test 1                      10%
Test 2                      15%
Test 3                      15%
Final exam              30%
Total                      100%

I would say that the grading is pretty fair.
The test and exam are relatively easy comparing to the professor of my friends. Terry included many questions from the homework in the test and final. If you study the homework hard and try to understand the mechanism behind, you can get good scores. For me, I recited some difficult mc and long q before the test and it was enough to deal with it. The mark for homework is based on the best 8 homework exercises out of 11.

my scores:
test 1: 190/200 (mean: 170 sd: 29.2)
test 2: 259.62/270 (mean: 78.38% sd: 14.85%)
test 3: 297.5/300 (mean: 87% sd: 14%)
final: not yet released till now
Homework: 100%

overall grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
There were homework through the CONNECT platform for each chapter. Each of them includes 10-20 mcq and 4-5 lq. It is crucial for you to understand the content of the chapter before doing it as only 3 tries are allowed. Score will be counted with the highest among the 3 tries.

It takes great amount of time to finish the homework as I have to go through the teaching slide before starting to do it. Near the end of the semester, the pace of teaching increases and homework are given out more rapidly. You are advised to finish the homework earlier before the deadline approaches as you can have more time to revise it for the test.

Overall, Terry is a nice professor and he is willing to provide assistance to his students. If you study the homework hard, you can get good grade in this course.

reviews.author: Ged
reviews.title: If you really want to learn something of acct and do not focus on grade only, Dennis is the best choice.
reviews.comment_content: Basic principles of internal accounting. The course will tell you how to record transactions and other things which may influence a company. If you haven't learnt anything about accounting before, it may take you some time to understand these things. These things are very important.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dennis has a relatively clear accent. You can understand his lecture easily. However, sometimes he talks a little bit fast. You have to follow his words. As a result, you may not have enough time to take notes.
He has good knowledge of this course. You can answer you immediately anything of this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Dennis is pretty strict with grades. You have to work hard.  BTW, the grade is not that transparent. At least this sem he didn't release anything about final exam.
Assessment: classworks 30%
                      HW 40%
                      Final 30% ( no midterm exam)
I got a B+
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy. Classwork and HW exert significant pressure on students, but these things can help you understand knowledge.

reviews.author: MattSWang
reviews.comment_content:
Covers Business, Accounting, and Financial Studies material taught for HKDSE students. Those who have taken the subject in secondary school will have a head start, but the content is still fairly easy to understand and approach if you haven't taken it.

The textbook was only for reference. All you need are his notes and handouts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very lively and passionate professor with a great sense of humor. Brings a lot of real-life examples into the classroom and simplifies complex concepts to make them more digestible. He speaks with clarity and authenticity as well. Very welcoming and open to questions, so approach him if you have any! He is very much willing to answer questions after classes and responds to emails very quickly.

One of the best professors I've ever had the pleasure of learning from. His patience and dedication is unparalleled and absolutely worth commending.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterms were fairly easy, but the final exam was extremely difficult. A minor mistake could be very costly to your standing in class. To be fair, he gave everyone a warning in advance so I had sufficient time to start doing practice questions to prepare for it. You had two days to do a take-home exam that was approximately thirty pages long. Make good use of every second! Don't hesitate to go back to your notes and re-check your calculations whenever possible.

He provides a very detailed breakdown of his grading. This transparency is very refreshing and appreciated, especially in comparison to other professors, some of which do not even tell you your performance in the assessments. I personally believe that in light of the exceptional situation at the time, his grading was more lenient than it would have been otherwise, but I believe that he is a fairly reasonable professor and don't see him giving incredibly harsh grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is fairly light. The assignments don't take too much time and practice exercises were given for the midterms. If you pay attention to his explanations in class you will have no problem doing well for the homework.

A generous amount of cheat sheets were allowed for the midterms.

reviews.author: vx
reviews.comment_content:
I've learnt accounting before so the content is relatively easy for me.


chp1 Introduction to the course and chapter 1
chp2 Investing and financing decisions and the accounting system
chp3 Operating decisions and the accounting system
chp4 Adjustments, financial statements, and the quality of earnings
chp5 Interpreting accounting information
chp6 Sales revenue, receivables, the bad debt
chp7 Cost of goods sold and inventory
chp8 Property, plant, and equipment
chp9 Reporting liabilities & bonds
chp10 Reporting liabilities & bonds
chp11 Reporting and interpreting stockholders’ equity
chp12 Statement of cash flows
chp13 Financial statement analysis

Chao actually skipped chp13 due to insufficient time. He didn't teach chp13 in the last class but gave us a review& QnA class instead.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite good. Chao is patient and willing to answer students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Homework 25%
Quizzes 30%
Final exam 40%

You need to answer the zoom polling questions to gain the participation marks.

There are five quizzes in total.  Each quiz makes up 7.5 points towards the final grade, and the
lowest of the five will be dropped. The quizzes are not so difficult, as long as you understand the concepts, do the smartbook exercises and textbook exercises, you will score high marks in the quizzes.

There are a lot of long questions in the final exam, which you need to spend a lot of time to understand the questions. You also need to be really careful when doing the calculation as there may be some traps in the questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is acceptable.

There are unlimited attempts for both the pre-class smartbook and post-class exercises.

I think the assignments are really good practices to fully understand the concepts.

reviews.author: stxfxtnx
reviews.title: EXTREMELY DIFFICULT FINAL
reviews.comment_content: I have studied BAFS in secondary school and the content is quite similar to the DSE syllabus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Chen is nice and passionate about teaching. She posts videos before lectures and you are suggested to finish the videos before the lectures as they are helpful for understanding the concepts. You can ask questions about the homework in class and she will answer those questions. Thus, if you have attended or watched lecture videos, it is not hard to get full mark in homework assignments.
She has also posted some additional exercise for students to practise more. While even if you have finished all the exercise, it does not guarantee that you can understand the questions in the final exam because the question types are totally different.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class discussions and exercises: 25%
In-class quizzes: 30%
Homework assignments: 20%
Final exam: 25%

It is very easy to get full mark in in-class discussions and exercises as you only have to finish the exercise and fill in your name then you will get full mark.
The in-class quiz after every chapter is quite easy and the mean is extremely high. Once you get wrong in one question, you will score below mean. While for comprehensive quizzes, they are much more challenging and require some calculations. The time is very tight and quite a number of students who haven't studied accounting before uni found it hard to complete the comprehensive quiz.
Unless you got an extremely low mark in the quizzes, if not, please remember NEVER SHIFT THE WEIGHT TO THE FINAL EXAM.
The mean of homework assignments is super high and nearly full mark. While for most assignments, you only have one attempt. For the last 2-3 assignments, you can have a second attempt while you will receive mark deduction.
The final exam is super hard. The questions are so long and just like English comprehensions. It is impossible to finish all the questions properly even for students who have studied accounting before.

I got full mark in in-class discussions and exercise, and homework assignments. Also, I got nearly full mark in the in-class quizzes. For the final exam, I only 79/218. The mean is around 65.5. Prof Chen later announced that the final total grade will be adjusted downward to around 150 points.
At last, I got an A- in this course
reviews.comment_workload: There is homework every week on Connect and each of them consists of around 10 questions. For me, I need at least one to two hour to complete it and make sure the answer is correct.

reviews.author: Joanna6
reviews.comment_content:
The level of difficulty of the content is appropriate
I didn't take take accounting in DSE, but the content is easy to understand for beginners.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen is very nice, she is very willing to answer question in and after class. And she usually responds very quickly.
Lecture videos are uploaded before class. They're short and easy to understand.
She will discuss important concepts in class and answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload
One quiz per chapter;
one hw assignment per chapter;
one group exercise per chapter (it's short and the answer will be discussed in class)

reviews.author: ಠ_ಠ
reviews.comment_content:
Libby, Libby, and Hodge. Financial Accounting, 10th edition (2019) Chapter 1-12 except chapter supplements and chapter 5

-Financial Statements and Business Decisions
-Investing and Financing Decisions and the Accounting System
-Operating Decisions and the Accounting System
-Adjustments, Financial Statements, and the Quality of Earnings
-Sales Revenue, Receivables, and Cash
-Cost of goods sold and inventory
-Property, plant, and equipment
-Reporting liabilities
-Corporate bonds
-Owners’ equity
-Statement of cash flows
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen is very nice and patient! Her English is fluent and easy to follow.

Lecture videos will be provided for each chapter, much more time is spent on optional Q&A session and mandatory group exercise/quizzes.

Professor Chen is willing to answer questions, if you still have questions, you can arrange a meeting with her and she will explain everything clearly!
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading system:
-In-class discussions and exercises (10 sessions) 25%
-In-class quizzes (10 quizzes) 30%
-Homework assignments (10 assignments) 20%
-Final exam 25%

The online final exam is difficult for me since I was not able to finish all the questions.(Remember not to apply for grade shift unless you got a very low mark in the quiz!) But you can still get a good grade if you work harder on assignments and quizzes as the final exam is only 25% of the course grade. An A range is not difficult if you score almost full marks for each assignment, group exercise and quiz.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is acceptable for me.
There is one assignment, one optional additional exercise and optional smart book reading for each chapter.
The questions in assignments and quizzes are similar to those in the textbook, so it is not difficult go get high marks for assignments if you study the textbook.

There is also group exercise and quiz for each chapter. A total of 8 chapter quizzes (2%) , 2 comprehensive quizzes (7%).

reviews.author: gagman
reviews.comment_content: financial accounting chapter 1-12 except chapter 5
reviews.comment_teaching:
1 there is preview slides and videos every week. only questions on classes.
2 good teaching
reviews.comment_grading:
above mean every quiz, group work, and final.
got B
one dude also in class got above mean in every quiz, group exercise and below mean in finals  get C+
reviews.comment_workload:
VERT BIG BIG BIG BIG BIG BIG
1 a quiz and a group exercise every week
2 2 comprehensive quizzes.
3 connect homework every week. quite a big workload. and most of them are very difficult.
4 do not expect to accomplish all questions in finals.

reviews.author: GPABaau4
reviews.comment_content: Basic acct
reviews.comment_teaching: He taught well. Explained everything clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair I guess.
Overall77.4% and B
He accepts lots of different answers as long as you give him your assumptions on the questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
His workload is, sorry for my language, shit.
All his assignments and midterm are take home  assignments. He gave like 72 hours each time. Basically everyone got help and the median is always full marks with mean 95%ish.
He said final exam looks like homework 3 but it didn’t. His description to his homework are always not accurate. If he says easy then it maybe normal but if he says difficult then it’s undoable ( rage quit using his own words).
He didn’t take attendance so I never attend class.

reviews.author: jab
reviews.comment_content:
Basic accounting knowledge (e.g.balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement, adjusting entries).
Easy for students with DSE BAFS background.
Slightly difficult contents: bond transactions, cash flow statement

*Easy for BAFS students to get a good grade. If you have not studied BAFS before, find another professor to get a good grade. His final is VERY difficult for beginners.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great professor with clear lecture slides. Lecture slides are straight forward and have a lot of examples. Yet his teaching would be a bit boring for students with DSE BAFS background. Study the lecture slides before quizzes would be good enough. He also prepares a study guide for each quiz, which is a summary of key concepts. The textbook solution will be posted on canvas once he finished the chapter.

Overall, he is a great professor with good teaching and excellent accent, but the final is just too difficult.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 5%
Homework 25%
Quizzes 30%
Final exam 40%

Participation: the score is based on how many polls you participated in during zoom meetings.

HW:
10 pre-class assignments and each one is 0.5 points, the grade is based on completion.
5 post-class problem sets and each one is 4 points, unlimited attempts.
SUPER heavy workload. Yet easy to get full marks if you are willing to spend time to finish them as they are based on completion and have unlimited attempts.

Quizzes: 5 MCQ quizzes, each quiz makes up 7.5 points towards the final grade, and the lowest of the five will be dropped.
*19 MCQs for each quiz*

Final Exam: 3x MCQs, the level of difficulty is much higher than the HWs or quizzes. It covers everything you learned in this course. No need to remember the statement formats, the MCQs focuses mainly on concepts.

*Some other professors have included ratios in their finals, but prof Tang did not teach nor test ratios in the final.

I got 80/100 in the final and full marks in participation, HW, and quizzes. Got A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload. Tons of HWs and quizzes. Each quiz covers two to three chapters. They are not difficult but very time-consuming.

reviews.author: solarski22
reviews.comment_content:
Some basic accounting knowledge.
If you haven't taken DSE Accounting, the content may be quite hard to follow; if you aren't interested in accounting, this course will be boring for you. Unfortunately, I have not taken DSE accounting and I am not interested in accounting at all... However, the professor has made the content not that boring by putting in some real life examples. I will talk more about it in the 'teaching' part. One more thing, the content before the midterm is quite easy to handle if you pay attention in class, but starting from the 'bonds' part, it is very hard to fully understand the content, extra effort is required to understand those abstract concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is nice, kind, he welcomes all questions, and will reply emails. But sometimes, the lectures will still be a little bit boring. Overall, it is a good learning experience with him. Nevertheless, when he went over the 'bonds' part, I personally think that he made the concepts a little bit difficult to follow, and he explained it quite unclearly. The examples in his notes is also not enough. By the way, we are required to remake the bonds examples using Excel in order to tackle the exam questions easily, it is though not bad, but time-consuming. Sometimes his slides are a little bit messy too.
Another point worth mentioning is that he will use some real-life companies such as Nike, McDonald's etc to explain some concepts. It is a very good approach, I will say. It is even more fantastic if you are interested in learning accounting.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Homework Quizzes 30%
Midterm 30%
Final exam 40%

- The midterm is easy, the homework quizzes are easy, however, the final exam is extremely hard and lengthy :(
- The means for midterm and homework quizzes are very high, sometimes even full mark. You have to pay attention to avoid making minor mistakes in order to touch the mean or even higher.
-Data:
HQs:
1. mean = 9/10 ; me: 9.5
2. mean = 9.55/10 ; me: 9.5
3. (no statistics) ; me: 11/15
Midterm: "The median score is 100/100 (i.e., most students got 100), and the average is 95.3/100" ; I got 96/100.
Final (disaster): "mean = 57.24" ; I got 54/100..
Final grade = B-

Below are something the professor mentioned in his email regarding the gradings for this semester, you will have to judge it yourself:
-"All exams have been graded fairly, accurately, and leniently and solutions for the final will not be posted."
-"Note that the lenient nature of the grading has given many students 50-60% points for complete attempts on certain questions even though the answers were incorrect."
-"There is no curve grading, but the cut-offs have been appropriately set after accounting for the difficulty level of the exams."

Good luck if you are in this section next year(s).
reviews.comment_workload: 3 homework quizzes. He will upload the quizzes about 48 hrs before the due time. You will have 'plenty' of time to do so. Nevertheless, I think the homework quizzes is a little bit time-consuming. Note that he required us to find the financial information from the internet ourselves, and sometimes we have to make all financial statements from nothing to everything using Excel, which costed a lot time. If you finally found out that the numbers are not balanced after working with it for 3 hrs, you will want to kill someone... It is a good practice though, I understood. Other than the homework quizzes, the only thing you have to do is to revise, and 'clear concept'; the good news is: no projects/presentations.

reviews.author: mikehuntisbald
reviews.title: Best prof in UST
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
1. Financial accounting around us
2. Balance sheet
3. Income Statement
4. Year end adjustments
5. Sales revenue + receivable
6. Property, plant and equipment
7. Liabilities
8. Owners equity
9. Cash flows

DSE讀過BAFS會輕鬆渡過， 不過都要留意有啲細節位同DSE唔同(e.g. Balance sheet格式、Depreciation method)，另外都有~20%係新嘢。
reviews.comment_teaching: Kelvin Mak係UST難得嘅好prof，我個人其他courses嘅prof都係為趕進度不斷飛slides / 讀一次slides就算，但Kelvin Mak會喺重點位作深入解釋，不惜cut syllabus都會堅持教好每個topic同每個學生有疑問嘅位。Kelvin Mak嘅教學理念令堂上有唔少notes抄，雖然我同意jot佢嘅notes係唔會幫到你考試 (lecture slides 已經足夠)，但你一定會對accounting有更透徹嘅理解，滿足到對知識嘅渴求。Mixed mode下我亦有到現場上lecture，Kelvin Mak課堂外都好願意答學生問題，UST清泉。
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 35%
Mid-term 25%
Final 40%

Homework易滿分，詳情睇workload
至於考試，Kelvin Mak嘅卷算簡單，但MC時間比較趕急，冇讀過BAFS隨時40題MC要撞十幾題

Homework: full mark
Mid-term: 216/240 (Mean 18X forgot)
Final: unknown (附上final LQ贖罪，冇答案)
最後A-

利申DSE BAFS level 4，如果5 or above應該輕鬆A range
reviews.comment_workload: Kelvin Mak係攞最高分嘅7份homework去計 (今個semester得8份)。homework雖然係1 attempt only，但可以重複check answer再交，有時有埋教學片lead住你做，平均20-30mins完成一份deadline 5-7日內homework，workload上算係十分友善。

reviews.author: 16y39y
reviews.title: reg sidd for a chill semester
reviews.comment_content:
Class 1: Course Overview
Class 2: Financial Statements
Class 3-4: Transactions and the reporting process
Class 5-6: Income Statement, Balance Sheet, Ratios and Cash Flow Statement
Class 7: Deferred, Prepaid and Accrued transactions
Class 8: Financial Statement Concepts
Class 9-10: Example 2 Journal Entries
Class 11-12: Income Statement, Balance Sheet, Ratios and Cash Flow Statement Revisited
Class 12-13: Other Journal Entries
Class 14: Operating Cycle
Class 15: Revenue Recognition
Class 16: Time Value of Money
Class 17: Liabilities
Class 18-19: Bonds
Class 20: Equity
Class 21: Conservatism Revisited

Pretty standard content for a foundation accounting course. I would say all of the content is useful. The content is generally easy to understand (except the Bonds part which took me two weeks to digest). Some people say that you'll have an advantage in this course if you have BAFS or high school accounting background, but I don't think it's that significant. I personally did DSE BAFS but with Sidd's teaching style and focus, many of the topics and concepts were new to me as well.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sidd is one of the best professors I've met at UST. He always prepares real-life examples to illustrate each of the concepts, which are easy to understand. In class, he often goes through financial statements of actual (big) US companies so you get a sense of the real world. He makes sure to explain concepts in the simplest way possible, which makes his lectures extra easy to understand.

He is also very very nice and seems to have endless patience answering questions. He takes time answering even dumb questions and you can feel that he genuinely cares about his students.

However, one small problem is that his notes are not the most structured. But it's not that major as I still have no problem understanding the content, I just need some time to organize it in my mind.
reviews.comment_grading:
In terms of grading homework quizzes and exams, he is very lenient. If you look at his marking schemes, he gives partial marks even for answers that are almost completely wrong, as long as you have made some sort of attempt. It's not hard to get partial marks from him.

That being said, almost everyone gets high scores for the homework quizzes and the midterm (most people got full marks for the midterm), so it almost fully depends on your final performance. Be mentally prepared that his final is significantly harder.

Components:
15% Higher of HWQ1 or 2
15% HWQ3
30% Midterm Exam (Median: 100, Mean: ~95)
40% Final Exam (Mean: 57.24, Max: 96)

Overall I scored 96.4% which resulted in an A+
(Thank you so much Sidd for saving my cga)
reviews.comment_workload:
Very very chill I love him so much.

Firstly, he doesn't count attendance which is already a major bonus. Secondly, unlike other professors (who gives timed quizzes and homework regularly throughout the semester), we only had 3 homework quizzes and a midterm exam, all of which were take home (~30 hours to do something that can be done in 2 hours).

The final is a bit painful though. The paper is very long but you only get 3 hours to do it. He explains that this is to prevent us from cheating, which I guess is a good idea since it makes the online exam fairer. The final exam is pretty much all the workload for the entire semester.

A piece of personal advice: just make templates and excel sheets for everything in advance and that will save you a lot of time in his final.

reviews.author: Hi_everyone

reviews.comment_content:
Basic accounting stuff, with the topics listed below:
1. Introduction
2. Basic journal entry and the accounting equation
3. The expanded accounting equation
4. Adjusting entry
5. The regulations in accounting
6. Bad debts
7. Inventory
8. PPE and depreciation
9. Present value and future value
10. The accounting for bonds
11. Treasury stocks, dividends, and stock splits
12. The statement of cash flow
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is generally good, and prof. is patient to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say grade of the course is solely based on the final exam, which takes 40% of the grade.

Actually, the assignment and problem set is meaningless as nearly everyone get a full marks in them.

The final is terrible. Very long with a lot of word problems, and the questions are extremely challenging.

I get 78/100 in the final, while the mean is 4x. This gives me an A+.

The grading system is enclosed in attachment.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is actually quite high.

There are 10 smart book assignments, 5 problem sets, and 5 quizzes in total.

reviews.author: lalalemon2345

reviews.comment_content: HKDSE Accounting level. The mid-terms are super easy, with mean being 87-9 usually and there are 2 mid-terms btw. His finals are quite hard for non-accounting students.

reviews.comment_workload: Many assignments (weekly); they only rely on completion rate; the quizzes in class are used for attendance purposes only.

reviews.author: Hart

reviews.comment_content:
Basis of Accounting
Chao's lecture notes are outstanding

Very well.
Explaining the concept clearly. Easy to follow up.

Curving. Classmates are very outstanding:)

reviews.author: kqjsun
reviews.comment_content: The content is all there but sometimes easy to get muddled. I've had no experience of accounting before this but this is easily rectified with a google search.
reviews.comment_teaching: I don't find Accounting terribly interesting but the professor is funny and entertaining, so I'm not bored to death despite my lack of interest in the subject
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is lenient, and probably especially so because of online/mixed mode.
reviews.comment_workload: Excel spreadsheets can take a while, but it's the nature of the subject. If HW is not Excel spreadsheets then usually it's to find something from the SEC website and to find a particular entry (in which ctrl-F/cmmd-F is your best friend)

reviews.author: Happypig375
reviews.title: Tang Chao is very nice!
reviews.comment_content:
Sep 8 Introduction to the course and chapter 1
Sep 10, 15 Chapter 2 - Investing and financing decisions and the accounting system
Sep 17, 22 Chapter 3 - Operating decisions and the accounting system
Sep 24, 29 Chapter 4 - Adjustments, financial statements, and the quality of earnings
Oct 1 (Public holiday)
Oct 6 Chapter 5 - Interpreting accounting information
Oct 8,13 Chapter 6 - Sales revenue, receivables, the bad debt
Oct 15, 20 Chapter 7 - Cost of goods sold and inventory
Oct 22, 27 Chapter 8 - Property, plant, and equipment
Oct 29 Chapter 9 - Reporting liabilities & bonds
Nov 3, 5, 10 Chapter 10 - Reporting liabilities & bonds
Nov 12, 17 Chapter 11 - Reporting and interpreting stockholders’ equity
Nov 19, 24, 26 Chapter 12 - Statement of cash flows
Dec 1 Chapter 13 - Financial statement analysis

We ended up skipping Chapter 13 to practice more in Chapter 12.

I really like this course. It is the introduction to all business terminology and has a lot of in-class exercises. Concepts such as bonds and treasury stock are what I had not understood before. This course is really beneficial to me.

The one gripe that I have with this course is that the digital textbook must be bought instead of the physical textbook (Libby, Libby, and Hodge. Financial Accounting, 10th edition (2018), McGraw-Hill/Irwin.). I can imagine someone buying the physical textbook only to find out that the McGraw-Hill Connect access code is not provided and have to spend money again.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. TANG, Chao encourages asking questions during class by monitoring blue hands in Zoom. He also speaks clearly when in his office but I needed to listen harder during the lectures that he gave in a real classroom during mixed-mode teaching. Recommendation: get a better microphone.

The in-class exercises are very helpful as they also act as a break between listening. The Zoom polling results are also useful since I can view the percentage of classmates with my answer as well. However, only the most popular answer is highlighted in red instead of blue. Not only can I not see what I have answered, but also I cannot see the correct answer and needed to pay extra attention to the lecturer. Not sure how this can be improved.

This course has a TA (Ms. CHAN, Ann) who did not appear in lectures at all who can only be reached by email. I cannot comment on her as I did not email her.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Participation: 5%
Homework: 25%
Quizzes: 30%
Final exam: 40%
Total: 100%

Each quiz has a maximum score of 7.5.

Sep 24 19:00-19:40 Quiz 1 (Chapter 1-3)
"Overall, you did a very good job on quiz 1. Here are some summary statistics of the grade. Average: 6.37 (85%); median: 6.7 (89%); Standard deviation: 1.02.
We figured out that Proctorio does not support the use of VPNs (see https://proctorio.com/support). Therefore, if you are in mainland China (or other places), you may run into trouble taking the quiz. Please send me an email, and we will address this issue.
If you missed quiz 1 because of other emergencies, please email me with the proof, and the weight will be shifted to the final (as stated in the syllabus). Otherwise, I will assume you give up the quiz."

Oct 8 19:00-19:40 Quiz 2 (Chapter 4-5)
"Here are some summary statistics for Quiz 2---Average: 6.54 (87.2%); median: 6.5 (90.7%); Standard deviation: 0.97. Many of you had significant improvement relative to quiz 1. Well done! As mentioned in class today, we will make two changes for future homework assignments and quizzes.
1. For problem set assignments, you will have unlimited attempts.
2. We will postpone quiz 3, 4, and 5 for one week so you have more time to study and prepare.  Please refer to the updated syllabus for the date of each quiz.
Once again, thank you all for your suggestions."

Oct 29 19:00-19:40 Quiz 3 (Chapter 6-7)
"The statistics for quiz 3 are as follows:
average: 6
median: 6.1
standard deviation: 1.55
This quiz is probably more challenging than the previous two. As mentioned in our class, the materials in later chapters are more difficult. So, if your grade was a little lower than expected, please don't feel frustrated. The lowest score of the 5 quizzes will be dropped. Have a great weekend."

Nov 19 19:00-19:40 Quiz 4 (Chapter 8-10)
"The statistics for quiz 4 are as follows:
average: 6.21
median: 6.5
standard deviation: 1.73
I am glad to see many of you have made a good improvement since quiz 3. Enjoy the weekend!"

Dec 3 19:00-19:40 Quiz 5 (Chapter 11-12)
"Quiz 5 results are as follows: mean 6.2, median 6.7, standard deviation 1.68.
In case you missed today's class, I want to clarify that
1) The final exam is likely more challenging than our quizzes. To help you better manage time, I put easier questions earlier and more difficult questions later.
2) It is advised that the camera should capture your hands and face during the exam. Since there is limited typing required to take the exam, the proctor may check with anyone who uses the keyboard a lot.
Best of luck and I wish you success in all your future endeavors."

Participation marks are obtained by participating in each Zoom poll each lecture. Wrong answers do not affect marks in this section, but not answering will lose marks. If 16 out of 20 polls are participated in, 4 out of 5 participation marks are obtained.

The homework consists of SmartBook assignments and Problem Sets. SmartBook assignments (0.5 points each) are for each chapter except 1, 5, and 13, where multiple-choice questions are answered repeatedly until 2 questions are answered correctly for each concept. The number of wrong answers does not affect the grade so this is where I can speedrun and find where I am not adequate quickly.

Problem Sets (4 points each) consist of 5 individual assignments where a few long fill-in-the-blank questions are answered. Originally, only 2 attempts are allowed but after the first Problem Set, it was loosened to unlimited attempts. The resulting mark of each Problem Set is the highest mark of any attempt.

I really like the quizzes where around 20 Multiple Choices are to be answered in 30 minutes with the Proctorio extension of Google Chrome to force a full screen and monitor the camera. Provided by the publisher, they allow for enough time to think about each question clearly and carefully, so I can score maximum marks each time. Moreover, he answers each question from students clearly and combined with logical slides, I am able to learn effectively. However, it messes with my dinner schedule on five Thursdays of these three months so I would like to see this changed.

Final Grade: A+ Thank you Tang Chao!!!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. Although there is homework, they actually replace self-study for the quizzes and the exam so in reality there is a very light workload.

reviews.author: xXAlvinXx

He also seems very professional and has rich experiences as he uses very concrete terms while speaking. reviews.author: studyislife
reviews.title: Not as easy as you think, good professor
reviews.comment_content:
Really solid accounting principles taught. Take this course seriously, it will be a life companion when you work in the financial industry in the future.
Covered contents like liabilities, time value of money, long-term assets, inventory....basically the components of the balance sheet, income sheet, and the SCF.
reviews.comment_teaching: Fantastic professor. Her English is very fluent, easy to follow in class. The way she teaches is great, using an iPad to illustrate all the ideas in class. Very approachable if you would like to ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
I didn't get a good grade, but that's simply because I didn't study well enough.
Quiz 1: 10/10 (5%, mean is 9)
Midterm: 14/30 (mean is 15.5)
Final: 40/100 (mean: 58)
I thought I am definitely getting a C or C+ but I actually got a B-, I know it's still bad but it's good given my performance.
The final went chaotic because it's the first time it goes online. Students at UST actually experienced a network issue during the exam so it was all very messed up. Lots of questions in the final so definitely no time to finish all, and they are not simple.... BUT it's only because it's online for the first time. I'm sure it will be better in the future.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a lot if you wish to achieve a higher grade.
Definitely attend all lectures, really pay attention. Read all the textbook content diligently and raise questions in class or in tutorials. Make sure you spend quality time in the subject.
Although I did quite a lot of past papers, attended all lectures, did everything she's asked for, apparently I just couldn't really understand the content. I know there are a lot of geniuses in UST, dragging the mean super high. So work your ASS OFF if you are someone like me who is super mediocre.

reviews.author: ggfgg
reviews.comment_content: questions are usually about simple stuffs will some traps. carelessness will kill u easily. as a student who didnt study acct before, it is a bit hard for me to fully understand all of the concepts by just attending the lectures, so efforts have to be paid.

reviews.comment_grading:
the mean is high.
there are 5 quizzes, and the 4 with the highest manrks will be graded.
30% quiz

25% hiomework
40% final
reviews.comment_workload: quite many assignments and u should pay attention to the due dates of each assignment as they are scheduled closely.

reviews.author: Edwin1025

reviews.author: Ritaleei
reviews.comment_content: Some basic knowledge about financial accounting. Using GAAP rules. Prof will teach you how to do financial statements. I think it is the most practical course for year1 business student.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Chao is new to HKUST. This is his 2nd year here.

Chao really speaks very fluent English. It is easy to understand. His lecture notes and lectures are really well-organized. If you listen carefully and review the notes well, even no need to read textbook.

Chao is also a nice person, he will be very patient to answer your question, explain until you really understand the content thoroughly.
reviews.comment_grading:
originally:
5% participation -- guess almost everyone got full
10% hw -- full mark if you show your efforts, no matter whether right or wrong
15% midterm1
20% midterm2 -- the 2 midterms are super easy, no need to worry if you grasp what Chao taught in class
50% final -- the final has super easy but also super difficult questions, especially when the teaching is switched online. The question is quite long and you have little time to read, think and compute.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not quite light if you want to get good grades. He will recommend to spend 8-10 hours a week working on this course. But I think this course deserve more hours.
The HW is not that too much and can be done within 1 hour.
You really need to work very hard for the final cuz it is cumulative. He will even test sth on textbook which he didn't cover in the lecture. Just try as hard as you can to read textbook and make sure you understand the logic behind everything.

reviews.author: gaohwy____
reviews.comment_content:
If you took BAFS-Acct in DSE, you will find it easy.
-Introduction and Chapter 1: Financial Statements
-Investing and Financing Decisions and the Accounting System (T-Accounts, Journal Entries)
-Operating Decisions (T-Accounts, Journal Entries)
-Adjustments, Financial Statements, and the Quality of Earnings (Creating the Balance Sheet, and Income Statement, Ratios, and Cash Flow Statement)
-Sales Revenue, Receivables, and Cash (Bad debt expense, credit sales, uncollectable receivables, aging of receivables)
-Cost of goods sold and inventory
(Methods of inventory costing)
-Property, plant, and equipment + Goodwill
(Purchase and sale of equipment, capitalization, amortization)
Operating Cycle (inventory turnover , payables outstanding, sales turnover, cash conversion)
-Time value of money
-Corporate bonds (bonds)
-Reporting liabilities (notes payable, contingent)
-Owners’ equity (Treasury stock, buybacks, preferred shares, dividends)
